Abstract:
The study of the pathophysiology of obesity is an important area of research. Studies have shown that obese individuals have a higher risk of insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes (T2D) compared to lean individuals. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the changes in metabolic markers in obese individuals after bariatric surgery and investigate whether these changes were influenced by the type of bariatric procedure performed. This quasi‐experimental study recruited obese individuals who underwent bariatric surgery between August 2018 and May 2019. 49 subjects were included, of which 26 received Roux‐en‐Y gastric bypass (RYGB), and 23 received sleeve gastrectomy (SG). Metabolic markers including Body Mass Index (BMI), lipid profile, fasting blood glucose (FBG), and homeostatic model assessment of insulin resistance (HOMA‐IR) were measured before and after surgery. Data were analyzed using paired t‐test and the chi‐square test. A p‐value of less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant. There was a significant reduction in BMI, FBG, total cholesterol, low–density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL‐C), and HOMA‐IR in both groups (p < 0.0001). There was no significant difference in BMI, total cholesterol, low–density lipoprotein

Abstract:
The aim of this study was to compare the effect of preoperative and postoperative exercise programs on recovery of lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in patients who underwent radical prostatectomy.A randomized controlled trial was conducted of men who underwent robot‐assisted laparoscopic radical prostatectomy between April and October2017. The subjects were divided into two groups: preoperative exercise training group group and postoperative exercise training group. A total of 60 participants were assigned to each group using a computer‐generated random number table. The exercise prescription included warm up, stretching, strength training, and aerobic training. The exercise group completed the training three times a week for 4 weeks prior to the surgery and 3 times a week for 6 weeks after the surgery. The exercise training was started approximately 6 weeks after surgery. The primary outcome measure was the IPSS score, and the secondary outcome measures included the QOL score, Mental health score, and body mass index.The IPSS and QOL scores were significantly lower at 6 weeks and 12 weeks after the surgery in the preoperative exercise training group than in the postoperative exercise training group. The mental health scores were significantly higher in the postoperative exercise training group than in the preoperative exercise training group. The body mass index was significantly higher in the postoperative exercise training group than in the preoperative exercise training group at the 12th week.Preoperative and postoperative exercise training had similar effects on the recovery of LUTS. The preoperative exercise training group had a lower IPSS and QOL scores than the postoperative exercise training group, indicating that longer exercise duration reduced postoperative side effects and improved recovery.Patients who underwent radical prostatectomy were enrolled in a study comparing preoperative and postoperative exercise programs for recovery from radical prostatectomy. The study results showed that preoperative exercise programs had a more significant effect on improvement of overall health, body mass index, and mental health than postoperative exercise programs.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: To assess a new screening tool used with the aim of reducing unnecessary investigations for patients with nonspecific chest pain.METHODS: A new diagnostic algorithm is evaluated in 120 consecutive patients with nonspecific chest pain with a chest pain centre in a district general hospital in the UK. Clinical data are gathered on the day of presentation at the centre. The tool, the 6‐item PREDICT scoring system is then used as soon as investigations have been done and the results considered.RESULTS: For 79 patients (66%) the tool recommended an invasive coronary investigation; the remaining 41 underwent a conservative management strategy which included an early non‐invasive ambulatory programme. Out of the 120 patients, 80 had a normal outcome, and 40 had an abnormal outcome confirmed initially or subsequently. Two patients with an abnormal outcome had their diagnoses made within 6 months, three had theirs made between 7 and 18 months, and two after 2.5 years. Forty‐eight (40%) of the 120 had a normal electrocardiogram (ECG), but only 21 (17.5%) had no abnormality on any of the investigations they had undergone.CONCLUSIONS: The 6‐item PREDICT scoring system is an effective tool in reducing the need for invasive coronary investigation.

The intervention group will receive the 14-hour MHFA course, while the control group will not. The study will take place in two stages and is expected to last for 12 months. The first stage will involve the delivery of the MHFA course and the second stage will involve a follow-up interview with participants to assess the impact of the course. The study aims to gather preliminary data on the feasibility, acceptability and impact of the course and provide insight into how to improve the course and make it more accessible to the target audience.

Abstract:
Pain is one of the most common and devastating symptoms for people with Alzheimer's disease (AD). It is also an important contributor to caregiver strain and burden. Despite its high prevalence, the pain assessment in patients with dementia continues to be a challenge; the pain is frequently under‐recognized and under‐treated. The purpose of this study was, thus, to investigate the feasibility and impact on pain measurement of using the Patient InformatioN for Intensive Care Evaluation scale, the pain scale validated for the intensive care units, on 36 patients with dementia and pain in a geriatric rehabilitation unit. Patients were admitted from an acute hospital and had been referred to geriatric rehabilitation for neurologic or orthopedic decompensation. Patients were randomly allocated into control and intervention groups. Each one received standard care for pain management (opioids, nonopioids, or topical treatments); the intervention group was assessed using the PINNICLE scale in addition. Nurses received training on its use, as well as on the recognition and management of pain. The PINNICLE scale demonstrated its feasibility to be used in the evaluation of pain of patients with dementia. It allowed to identify painful situations, and even to detect a previously unrecognized pain condition. It was also possible to improve pain management and reduce medication use. Pain must be considered an essential clinical dimension of patients with dementia. The PINNICLE scale may be an important tool to improve management of pain for these patients.

Abstract:
It is very common to find papers presented in conferences to report the latest findings but where the data are not yet fully validated and conclusions are often preliminary. This calls in question the legitimacy of reporting the research, and we can argue that it is not fully peer‐reviewed, or published. In addition, most of these proceedings papers are not published in scholarly journals, which may cast doubt on their quality. To improve these shortcomings, proceedings papers have been assigned a new status: Conference Proceeding (CP). This status has been defined as "a conference paper that appears in the proceedings of a conference or symposium", and is a good alternative to reporting preliminary results that have not yet been peer‐reviewed. This new status should help to clarify the situation, as it clearly distinguishes between preliminary results and peer‐reviewed findings.

Abstract:
AIM: The first aim of the present study was to develop a questionnaire for evaluating quality of life (QoL) before and after total hip arthroplasty (THA). The second aim involved validating the questionnaire in a study that consisted of 50 patients that have undergone THA. The final aim focused on determining whether the score on the questionnaire reflects a significant improvement in health‐related QoL (HR‐QoL).MATERIALS AND METHODS: The QoL‐50 questionnaire was developed using the method of test‐retest, reproducibility, and content validity. Fifty patients that have undergone THA are being used to test the face and concurrent validity of the questionnaire. We validated the developed questionnaire by comparing its sensitivity to the standard score of the generic EQ‐5D‐5L and the disease‐specific Short From Hip Scale (SF‐12).RESULTS: Based on qualitative analysis, 10 items were selected as QoL criteria. The mean QoL score of patients pre‐ and postoperatively was 1.51 ± 0.28 and 3.47 ± 0.23, respectively. The Cronbach's alpha of the questionnaire was 0.75. The QoL questionnaire showed high reliability for QoL changes (ICC = 0.98, P < 0.001). However, it showed slight agreement with the EQ‐5D‐5L questionnaire (ICC = 0.16, P < 0.001). The SF‐12 questionnaire exhibited slightly greater agreement (r = 0.79, P < 0.01).CONCLUSIONS: In conclusion, the results of this study indicate that the QoL‐50 questionnaire is a valid instrument for detecting HRQoL changes before and after THA. Abstract:
Sexual Dysfunction in Breast Cancer Survivors: A Survey Study among Egyptian Women on Breast Cancer Exercise Program (BeX‐II)

Abstract:
Introduction: The prevalence of sexual dysfunction in breast cancer survivors is high. Therefore, this study investigated the prevalence of sexual dysfunction among breast cancer survivors who received breast cancer exercise program (BeX‐II) using the female sexual function index (FSFI) among breast cancer survivors in Gastroenterology Surgical Oncology in Faculty of Medicine Assiut University, Egypt. Methods: A cross‐sectional randomized controlled trial was done. A total of 108 breast cancer survivors were selected randomly out of the patients who were referred by the oncology department of University Hospital, Assiut University for breast cancer exercise program (BeX‐II) between November 2021 and September 2022. The FSFI questionnaire that consists of questions about desire, arousal, lubrication, orgasm, satisfaction, and pain. Results: Total of 76 breast cancer survivors participated in the study, with an average age of 59 ± 8.9 years. The majority of the respondents were married (54.7%), living with husband (67.1%), not working (65.8%), and have 1 child (78%). The prevalence of sexual dysfunction in this study was found to be 84.2% (75/76), of which 78.9% (59/76) have a serious level of sexual dysfunction, and 18.4% (14/76) did not have sexual dysfunction. Conclusion: A comprehensive and integrated approach to addressing sexual dysfunction in breast cancer survivors should be instituted to provide adequate medical, psychological, and social support to these women. Thus, nursing counseling, nursing support groups, and exercise have an important role in improving sexual health awareness and education. The study findings can be used as the baseline for further studies.

Study Overview

Brief Summary

Patients were divided randomly into two groups 1 and 2. Group 1: Patients received a combined dose of paracervical anesthesia and intrathecal fentanyl and ropivacaine and group 2 without fentanyl. The comparison of the two groups was in terms of the time to first request analgesia dose after surgery. In addition, postoperative pain intensity, adverse reactions such as nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and sedation.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study was to assess the efficacy of combined ropivacaine and fentanyl compared to ropivacaine alone in epidural anesthesia for cesarean section. In this study, eligible patients were randomized to 2 groups to receive either a paracervical anesthetic containing 0.25% ropivacaine 12 ml plus fentanyl 50 micrograms or a comparable dosage of intrathecal opioids. After surgery, patients whose postoperative pain intensity was 4 or greater were given 10 mg morphine IV as required for relief.

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To determine the safety and efficacy of a single dose administration of an amniotic ﬂuid stem cell (AFSC) suspension for knee arthritis.METHODS: This was a phase 2, proof‐of‐concept study of intracapsular 1‐day intravenous (IV) administration of freshly separated amniotic fluid‐derived stem cells in patients with mild osteoarthritis (OA) of the knee (n = 19). Fourteen patients each received AFSC suspensions using two different formulations. The first four patients of both formulations acted as their own control.RESULTS: Two‐dimensional and three‐dimensional images of magnetic resonance images (MRI) and computed tomography (CT) images were obtained before and 3‐months following AFSC administration for all patients. Synovitis and bone regeneration occurred in most patients with or without intra‐articular hyaluronic acid (HA) use. A significant decrease in synovial fluid viscosity was observed after AFSC administration. Mild side effects were observed, such as pain (n = 4), swelling (n = 2), and fever (n = 1). However, all side effects disappeared within seven days.CONCLUSION: The AFSC is a promising treatment candidate for OA with mild or moderate symptoms. Further studies are needed to determine the clinical utility of AFSCs in OA treatment.

Introduction: While there is consensus that cancer treatments significantly impair physical function, there has been little attention paid to whether cognitive function is similarly affected. This could be particularly noteworthy in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) at high risk for cognitive decline. A previous meta-analysis demonstrated no significant cognitive changes with HNSCC treatment. However, no studies included patients with cognitive impairments and/or delirium at enrollment. Furthermore, all studies had a low risk of bias. The purpose of this study is to compare baseline cognitive function prior to initiation of treatment between newly diagnosed HNSCC patients with high risk for cognitive decline versus without using a validated tool. Method: Patients were recruited to the Neuro-Onco-Supportive-Treatment (NOST) clinical care trial at the University of Maryland (NCT03057184). Patients were randomized into the control arm vs the cognitive support intervention arm. High-risk criteria for cognitive decline included at least one prior stroke or moderate-to-severe cognitive impairment per screening assessment tools. For cognitive impairment, the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) was used. Answering 6 or less questions correctly indicates mild-to-moderate cognitive impairment. The cognitive support arm includes a cognitive enhancement protocol. Controls undergo standard symptom care per standard oncology care. Primary objective of the NOST trial is to determine the time to post-treatment cognitive decline (TCMD). Differences in TCM with cognitive impairment and without between arms will be reported according to the intent to treat (ITT) model. Secondary objective includes evaluating the feasibility of the cognitive protocol. Results: Preliminary data will be presented. Limitations: We anticipate high dropout rate due to the nature of the trial. Conclusion: This study will allow investigators to evaluate the degree of cognitive impairment within this high-risk group at baseline and compare the frequency of treatment induced cognitive decline (TDIC), comparing between the control and cognitive support arms of the NOST trial.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The objective of the study is to evaluate and compare the effect of different types of music on anxiety, pain, satisfaction in patients undergoing colonic examination. The effect of classical and religious music on anxiety, pain and satisfaction in patients undergoing colonic examination will be evaluated. The music will be provided by an earphone to the patients undergoing colonic examination by an ultrasonography probe attached to their shoulder. The subjects will be randomly assigned to experimental group and control group. The subjects in the experimental group will listen to the music of their choice. The subjects in the control group will not listen to any music.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The method of this study was developed by Hattori et al in 2007 from Tokyo, Japan. They demonstrated that music reduces anxiety and pain during a colonoscopy examination. The effects of music on anxiety during colonoscopy have been evaluated since 1980. The aim is to reduce anxiety and pain, and to increase patient satisfaction with the examination. However, despite the widespread use of music, there have been no previous studies in endoscopy clinics regarding the effect of music on anxiety, pain and patient satisfaction in the colonoscopy procedure. Colorectal cancer, which is the most common cancer in our country, affects about 7.4% of the population and is the second most common cause of cancer mortality in the world. Early diagnosis and treatment with rapid colonoscopy play a very important role in mortality and morbidity. Colonoscopy is a simple, noninvasive procedure and the golden standard for screening and symptom evaluation. In addition, with the use of conscious sedation, it can be performed as painless as possible without any harm to the patient. However, many patients have phobia and anxiety due to colonoscopy. Patients often experience anxiety and stress during the colonoscopy procedure. Colonoscopy with conscious sedation may cause side effects or complications related to sedation. Patients often experience some pain, anxiety and drowsiness during a colonoscopic examination.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary purpose of this program is to observe real world effectiveness and tolerability, and to evaluate the immunogenicity, of dupilumab for the treatment of moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis in routine clinical practice in Canada and Europe during a 1 year period following the indication extension to moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis. The study will also evaluate healthcare resource usage and quality of life (QOL).

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is an open-label, observational, longitudinal, multicenter prospective real-world study of adult and pediatric patients with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis initiating dupilumab in routine clinical practice in Canada and Europe. Eligible patients will be seen at regular clinic visits during the duration of the observational period. At each visit, investigators will collect demographic information, disease severity, medication adherence, and overall symptoms through questionnaires on patient health-related quality of life and disease and skin symptom severity. The investigators will also collect information on biologic treatment history and treatment side effects, healthcare resourcing in the form of doctor and patient service use/costs, and information for calculating overall treatment costs and cost per unit of skin clearance.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of the proposed study is to evaluate the effectiveness of the Unified Protocol for the Treatment of Emotional Disorders (UP) in adults living with Multiple Sclerosis (MS) with comorbid depression and/or anxiety. The purpose of the research is to evaluate the efficacy of the UP as an adjunctive intervention to the MS-specific cognitive-behavioral therapy (MS-CBT) and determine if its use is superior to the use of a waitlist control. It is hypothesized that participants assigned to the UP + MS-CBT condition will show a greater reduction in depressive symptomology, anxiety symptomology, and MS-specific distress than those assigned to the MS-CBT only or waitlist control conditions.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Rationale: Depression and anxiety are commonly reported symptoms in individuals living with a chronic illness such as MS, with rates approaching 50%. These symptoms can lead to decreased quality of life, decreased functioning, and adherence to treatment plans. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is a recommended evidence-based therapy for depression and anxiety that has been shown to be effective in reducing symptoms in individuals with MS. However, CBT is often not available or accessible to individuals living with MS, and it is often difficult to find practitioners with expertise in delivering both CBT and a cognitive approach to depression and anxiety in this population. The Unified Protocol for the Treatment of Emotional Disorders (UP) is a CBT-based intervention that has been shown to be effective in reducing the symptoms of depression and anxiety in multiple populations and formats, including in-person settings, telehealth delivery, and as an individual and group modality. The UP has not been adapted for individuals with MS. This proposed pilot study will evaluate the effectiveness of the 12-week UP + MS-specific CBT in an adult population of MS. The objective of this pilot study is to evaluate a revised UP that has been modified to address MS-specific issues. Based on feedback, it is envisioned that the UP

Abstract:
Aims. The aim of the trial is to study the effectiveness of the Unified Protocol on emotion dysregulation in patients with asthma.Methods. Fifty‐six patients, 34 females and 22 males, 55.73 +/‐ 16.68 years old with diagnosis of asthma will be recruited. They will be assigned randomly to treatment or control groups (n = 28). The treatment group will receive the Unified Protocol of Transdiagnostic Treatment of Emotional Disorders for 12 weeks, whereas the control group will not receive any intervention. The primary outcome will be assessed by the Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (ERQ) at baseline, post‐treatment, 6‐week, 6‐month, and 12‐month follow‐up. The secondary outcome will comprise quality of life (as measured by the Asthma‐QoL), anxiety, depression, sleep, and mindfulness assessed at each assessment with the corresponding scale. A repeated‐measures ANOVA will be performed on outcome measures. Results. Preliminary data have been obtained in the first 23 patients enrolled (15 females and 8 males, mean age: 45.22 +/‐ 18.84 years old). Compared to baseline, patients experienced a significant improvement for the outcomes assessed at 12 weeks after the end of the intervention in the treatment group (n = 13) compared to the control group (n = 10) measured by ERQ, SF‐36, BDI‐II, VAS‐AS, VAS‐S, PSQI, and ASQ.Conclusion. So far, patients receiving the Unified Protocol showed significant improvement in comparison with the control group at 12 weeks after the end of the intervention. Study of Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics of Hydrocortisone in Posthemorrhagic Patients With Vitamin K Dependent Bleeding

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to characterize the pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic profiles (the way the drug moves through the body and affects the body) of hydrocortisone in preterm infants with or without vitamin K dependent bleeding. The drug (hydrocortisone) used in this study is used frequently among critically ill infants, but the dose and length of time these drugs are used, and how long the drug stays in the body are unknown. For safety reasons, it is important to know about the metabolism (breakdown) and elimination (removal) of these drugs to help guide the dose and how long to give it to patients. Also, hydrocortisone binds to a certain protein in the blood while it takes a little time to reach the correct level. This study aims to help define how long the drug takes to reach the right level and how long it stays in the body. This study aims to enroll 22 very premature infants weighing up to 1000 grams after birth who are diagnosed with vitamin K dependent bleeding. Patients will be treated with hydrocortisone to manage bleeding. Blood will be withdrawn 4 times within 7 days for testing.

OBJECTIVES: The current study aimed to prospectively assess the safety of a new drug treatment in patients with Parkinson disease (PD) or multiple system atrophy (MSA) who received intraprocedural dexmedetomidine (DEX‐IP) during awake surgery for stereotactic ablative therapy.BACKGROUND: The drug is widely used during surgical procedures in patients with a variety of conditions. In addition, some patients receiving DEX‐IP therapy during awake surgery (AS) showed improvement in quality of life and cognition. Our pilot study is a single‐arm, prospective study which evaluated the safety and performance of DEX‐IP in patients who underwent AS for movement disorder. METHODS: The study design consisted of evaluation of safety, feasibility, and the effects of treatment on cognition and mood. Patients' safety, adverse events, and vital signs were assessed. Adverse events were defined as serious adverse events during AS and within 7 days. Cognitive and mood status were assessed by the Montreal Cognitive Assessment scale and the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS). RESULTS: We conducted AS in 40 patients. The mean age was 66.3±10.1 years, and 85% of the total patients (n = 34) were male. The mean duration of AS was 91.47±36.01 min, and the mean infusion time of DEX‐IP was 77.43±28.66 min. The most frequent adverse event was bradycardia, followed by hypotension, which often occurred during AS. No serious adverse events occurred. Abstract:
This prospective, multicenter, open‐label pilot study evaluated the effect of two sequential doses of SABER‐7 in participants with inadequate infections despite optimal parenteral antibiotic therapy. Eighty‐nine patients with osteomyelitis were enrolled and randomly assigned to either the SABER‐7 treatment group (24) or the control group (23) consisting of participants who continued parenteral antibiotics. In the treatment group, SABER‐7 was infused at a dose of 540 μg on day 1 and 160 μg every 6 weeks (weeks 2, 4, , , 60, 74, and 84) in addition to parenteral antibiotics. Participants in the control group received only parenteral antibiotics for a maximum of 12 weeks from the start of the study. The primary end point was the change in the C‐reactive protein (CRP) level between baseline and week 60. Baseline demographics and CRP levels at baseline and week 60 were comparable among the treatment and control groups. Among 20 participants with CRP levels >1.5 mg/L at baseline, the CRP level decreased in 17 (85%) participants in the SABER‐7 group and in three (15%) participants in the control group by week 60 (P = 0. 001 for between‐group difference). The proportion of patients with CRP levels <0.5 mg/L was significantly higher in the SABER‐7 group (93%) than in the control group (44%) at week 60 (P = 0. 003). [DESIGN] In this prospective study, we will include patients presenting to our institution with acute vertebral fractures and determine their eligibility for the study by the study inclusion and exclusion criteria. Initially, we will use clinical evaluation and imaging studies to assess the patient's condition and ensure that they meet the inclusion criteria. Then, informed consent will be obtained for patients who are deemed eligible. Before surgery, we will obtain preoperative radiographs, CT scans, and MRIs. The surgical technique will be performed as follows: After positioning the patient prone, a posterior transpedicular approach will be used to enter the vertebral body through a 10- to 15-mm incision on the posterolateral aspect of the spine. The pedicle and superior and inferior endplates will be identified and reamed to create a channel. A balloon will then be inserted into the channel and inflated to create a cavity within the vertebral body. After deflating and removing the balloon, porous titanium microspheres will be filled into the cavity using a cannula. The excess material will be removed, and the wound will be closed appropriately. Postoperative management will consist of bed rest for 3 days, followed by ambulation and rehabilitation as tolerated. Postoperative imaging studies will be obtained to ensure proper placement of the microspheres and assess any complications. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled at 3, 6, and 12 months for clinical and radiographic assessment. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of the study is to determine whether blood pressure lowering is similar between patients on the usual calcium intake (500 to 2000 mg/day) and another group of patients on a high calcium intake from non-dairy sources (supplemented 3000 mg/day).

Detailed Description
-----------------
Blood pressure is a key risk factor for heart disease, which is the leading cause of death globally. Although calcium is known to lower blood pressure, the optimal amount is not known in patients with or at risk of hypertension. This is a two-way crossover, randomized, controlled trial involving subjects with or at risk of hypertension. Subjects will be randomized to two arms, 1. Control (standard therapy and standard calcium) or 2. Intervention (standard therapy and high calcium). Subjects will receive high calcium for 3 months, then crossover to Standard Calcium for 3 months before completing the study with a final visit. The primary outcome measure of interest is the change in blood pressure throughout the study. Secondary outcome measures of interest are the changes in pulse wave velocity, aortic distensibility, brachial Augmentation Index and carotid femoral pulse wave velocity, and adverse events.

Official Title
-----------------
Efficacy of High Non-dietary Calcium Supplementation to Lower Blood Pressure in Patients With or at Risk for Hypertension

Conditions
-----------------
Systemic Hypertension

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Drug: High calcium

Abstract:
Introduction: Eating disorders can negatively affect the quality of life, increase the risk of suicide, and cause various physical and psychological health problems. The aim of this study was to determine the effectiveness of a motivational interviewing intervention on attitudes, beliefs, and self‐esteem in people with eating disorders. Methods: This study was a two‐group pre‐test and post‐test experimental design. The sample of this study included 30 patients with eating disorder. It was collected in stages 1 and 2 under the supervision of the researcher and in stages 3 and 4 by a trained therapist. After training both counselor groups and patients at home, the control group received routine care, but the intervention group was counseled using motivational interviewing for 4 sessions. Then, two weeks after counseling, the counselor and participants were evaluated. SPSS 22 was used to analyze and code the data, and the statistical population was compared using the t‐test. Results: The intervention group reported a significant difference in attitudes, beliefs, and the quality of life and self‐esteem before and after the intervention compared to the control group (p<0.0001). Conclusion: Motivational interviewing was an effective method in helping patients with eating disorders overcome negative attitudes and beliefs about themselves and their disease.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a single-arm, dose-escalation study of BGB-A317/ADCT-301 in 18 - 25 year-old young adults and 60 year and older elderly patients with high risk newly-diagnosed DLBCL . The study will be conducted at approximately 20 hospital sites in the United States and Europe. Eligible patients must have been newly diagnosed, untreated aggressive large B cell lymphoma of the following histologic subtypes: T cell/Histocytic, T Cell Rich, Double HIT and NK cell lymphomas. Previous studies have shown that the B cell component of these aggressive lymphomas represents approximately half of the tumor. The BGB-A317 and ACT-301 components of this combination will target T cells and CD19+ B cells; thus, this combination targeted treatment is expected to impact two cells of the tumor (T+B+). In addition, the B cell component of this combination targeted treatment is expected to impact a previously untreated B cell component and may be expected to impact the efficacy of the treatment; this will be the key hypothesis of this study. The objective of the study is to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) or recommended Phase 2 dose (RP2D) of BGB-A317 and ACT-301 when used in combination to treat B cell lymphomas in this patient population.

Official Title

A Phase 1 Study Of BGB-A317 Combined With ACT-301 In Patients With Newly Diagnosed Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma

Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma

Abstract:
Background:
-----------------
The current study aims to assess the effectiveness of acitretin in reducing acneiform rash in non‐acne‐specific guttate erythematosus (GAE). Methods:
Forty‐one Egyptian patients presenting with GAE were included in the current study. All patients were treated with 30 mg/day of acitretin over 2 months. At the end of 2 months, the erythema and acneiform rash and total score were evaluated monthly by 2 blinded dermatologists. Results:
The total median baseline score was 5 (IQR: 3‐6) and decreased to 2.5 (IQR: 1‐4) after 2 months of treatment (p=0.002). At the end of the second month, 16 patients (38.8%) showed a complete response and 18 (43.8%) showed a partial response, while 7 patients (17.4%) had no response or deterioration. Conclusion:
----------------‐
This study demonstrates the effectiveness of acitretin in reducing acneiform rash in non‐acne‐specific GAE. A larger, randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, and comparative trial are warranted to support our preliminary findings.

The use of oral retinoids in guttate erythematosus (GAE) has been traditionally reported in the literature. Retinoids are known to exhibit anti‐inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties which are similar to those of topical corticosteroids. As such, they play a role in the treatment of various inflammatory and dermatological conditions. As corticosteroids are usually the first‐line treatment for GAE, the efficacy of retinoids has not been adequately compared to those of corticosteroids.
Acneform rash that resembles the picture of acne vulgaris is frequently reported in GAE patients. Acneform rash is most commonly located on the upper extremities, neck

Inclusion Criteria:
1. Male and female adult participants ≥18 years of age at the time of signing the informed consent.
2. CSU duration for ≥ 6 months prior to screening.

7. Willing and able to complete an Urticaria Patient Daily Diary (UPDD) for the duration of the study and adhere to the study protocol.
8. Participants must not have had more than one missing UPDD entry (either morning or evening) in the 7 days prior to randomization (Day 1).

Exclusion Criteria:
1. Prior exposure to ligelizumab, omalizumab, and other biologics with any effect in CSU, including anti-IgE therapies.
2. Significant bleeding risk or coagulation disorders.
3. History of gastrointestinal bleeding.
4. Requirement for anti-platelet or anti-coagulant medication.
5. History or current hepatic disease.
6. Evidence of clinically significant cardiovascular, neurological, psychiatric, pulmonary, renal, endocrine, metabolic, hematological disorders, gastrointestinal disease, or immunodeficiency.
7. Evidence of helminthic parasitic infection as evidenced by stools being positive for a pathogenic organism according to local guidelines.
8. Documented history of anaphylaxis.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study has developed a perfusion software method based on PET/CT perfusion perfusion images of the skeletal muscles. This study is to evaluate the new perfusion software method in comparison to an existing software method based on venous sampling. This study will enroll a total of 25 patients with a suspected local malignant tumor. Patients with PET/CT positive findings in the abdomen, chest, or pelvis will be evaluated. The skeletal muscles of all the patients will be imaged using PET/CT perfusion perfusion images. The perfusion perfusion signals will be obtained using both software methods and then compared visually by a specialized radiologist.

Detailed Description
-----------------
PET is a functional image method that quantitatively evaluates abnormalities in organs by tracing metabolic changes in tissues based on the principle of positron emission, and CT performs cross-sectional imaging using radiation. When used together, the PET/CT integrated system is called PET/CT perfusion perfusion. The study method is based on PET/CT perfusion perfusion. It scans the abdomen, chest, and pelvis. The scan can be considered for the following patients. Abnormalities in 18F-FDG uptake on PET/CT perfusion imaging are often considered indications of local malignant tumors, but abnormal signals may also be found in benign lesions such as inflammatory tissue. If the location, extent, and shape of the lesion are unclear, additional investigations such as biopsies are required. In addition, if there is more than one lesion, it is difficult to determine which lesion is responsible for the abnormality by PET/CT perfusion imaging. This study is a prospective study of 25 adult male or female patients at SNUBH Hospital who were suspected or diagnosed with a local malignant tumor based on 18F- FDG PET/CT perfusion

You're absolutely right. By excluding participants with a history of DVT, we can minimize potential risks or complications associated with compression therapy.

*DVT refers to the formation of a blood clot (thrombus) in a deep vein, typically in the leg. It can be a serious condition that requires medical attention.

*Compression therapy involving the use of compression garments can provide graduated pressure to assist venous return and improve circulation. However, it is important to ensure that participants who have had a history of DVT are not at an increased risk of developing further complications if they engage in compression therapy.

It is recommended that healthcare providers evaluate each participant's individual medical history and ensure that compression therapy is safe for them.


Here are some additional points to consider in relation to the exclusion criterion for participants with a history of DVT:

1) Potential risks associated with compression therapy: Compression therapy can potentially increase venous pressure and blood flow in the deep veins, which could increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or other complications for participants with a pre-existing condition like DVT.
2) Medical evaluation: Participants with a history of DVT should undergo a thorough medical evaluation before enrolling in a study that involves compression therapy. This evaluation should include a review of the participant's medical history, a physical examination, and appropriate diagnostic testing to assess the risk of developing further complications.
3) Follow-up and monitoring: Participants with a history of DVT should be monitored closely for any signs or symptoms of possible complications during the intervention period, including inflammation, pain, or swelling in the legs. If any concerns arise, prompt medical attention should be sought.

*DVT stands for Deep Vein Thrombosis, which refers to the formation of a blood clot (thrombus) in a deep vein, typically in the leg. It can be a serious condition that requires medical attention and can lead to complications like pulmonary embolism (PE) if the clot dislodges and travels to the lungs.

Study protocol
=================
Brief summary in scientific language
=================
The study aims to develop a novel device for the non-invasive measurement of end-tidal carbon dioxide (NIST-ECCO2) in children during general anaesthesia. The measurement of end-tidal carbon dioxide has proven to be especially important during general anaesthesia in order to quickly detect possible hyper- and hypoventilation in the patient and to optimise ventilation according to these results. However, many of the current devices for non-invasive measurement of end-tidal carbon dioid are unreliable in children due to the use of a pneumo-tachograph or a mask capnometer in conjunction with a gas analyser. In addition, the use of these devices leads to an increase in dead space and work of breathing, and as a result to a deterioration of the patients' respiration.
The aim of the present study is to develop a device for the non-invasive measurement of end-tidal CO2 that is based on the measuring method of the NIST-ECCO2, which is a device for the invasive measurement of end-tidal CO2 using blood. This NIST-ECCO2 method has shown very good accuracy in adults, so the idea now is to adapt the non-invasive method of the NIST-ECCO2 to children. This can be done based on the fact that capnography in children and adults is based basically on the same physical principle, namely the Henry's law - which says that the CO2 content in the air is proportional to the partial pressure and CO2 concentration in the blood. Thus, the present study uses the same mathematical model of NIST-ECCO2, but this time with the aim of measuring the exhaled CO2

PURPOSE: We compared the outcomes of total laryngectomy versus hemilaryngectomy for treatment‐naïve locally advanced larynx carcinoma (LAH‐TCN). Patients and Methods: This retrospective study compared 83 patients who underwent hemilaryngectomy from January 2009 to September 2020 with 67 patients who underwent total laryngectomy from January 2011 to September 2020 at a tertiary referral center in Tokyo. The primary endpoint was 5‐year overall survival (OS), and the secondary endpoints were 5‐year disease‐specific survival (DSS), 5‐year failure‐free survival (FFS), and 5‐year progression‐free survival (PFS). Kaplan‐Meier method was used to compare the OS, DSS, FFS, and PFS rates. Cox‐proportional hazards regression analysis was employed to assess the effects of surgery type, treatment regimen, and other clinicopathological factors on OS. Statistical significance was established at P < 0.05. RESULTS: The 5‐year OS, DSS, FFS, and PFS rates did not significantly differ between hemilaryngectomy and total laryngectomy. The risk of distant metastasis in the total laryngectomy group was higher than in the hemilaryngectomy group (P = 0.034). The overall proportion of patients who developed complications after surgery did not significantly differ between the two groups (P = 0.553). Distant metastasis was the primary factor influencing OS (P < 0.001). BACKGROUND: Neuro‐oncology represents an emerging and dynamic specialty. In order to develop a comprehensive list of recommended competencies for neuro‐oncology, the Joint Section on Neuro‐Oncology of the American Association of Neurosurgeons and the Congress of Neurological Surgeons conducted a survey of fellowship‐training program directors to identify competencies important in the field of neuro‐oncology. The purpose of this study was to review this survey and report on the most commonly reported, important competencies required for competent neuro‐oncology fellowship training.METHODS: Two e‐mail surveys were sent to all neuro‐oncology fellowship program directors. The first survey contained open‐ended questions asking about competencies (knowledge, skill, and attitude) that are important to the practice of neuro‐oncology. The survey also asked about specific areas of neuro‐oncology in which competency may be lacking among trainees. The second survey followed and listed the responses from the first survey. The survey listed and ranked the listed competencies. Survey participants were asked to choose the 5 competencies they deemed most important and to also evaluate their fellowship program's overall preparation in the respective area.RESULTS: Nineteen surveys (100%) were completed by neuro‐oncology fellowship program directors (11 from academic centers and 8 from private practices). A number of critical competencies were cited on both surveys, including radiation oncology (academic 90.9%, private 100%), medical oncology (academic 81.8%, private 62.5%), neurosurgery (academic 81.8%, private 62.5%), stereotactic radiosurgery (academic and private 76.9%), and surgical oncology (academic 76.9%, private 62.5%). After 6 months ofART initiation, both 5‐MCT levels and CD4 values were significantly increased in group 1 and in group 3, respectively. There was no significant change in group 2 despite the introduction of ART. Abstract:
Background: Pretreatment chemotherapy (CT) and postoperative radiation therapy (PORT) are often utilized in the management of patients with breast cancer. The aim of this study was to assess the quality of life (QoL), body function, and symptoms in breast cancer patients and to evaluate the association between PORT and QoL after CT. Methods: A total of 172 patients were divided into 2 groups: CT ‐ RT group (n = 79), and CT + RT group (n = 93). Demographic and clinical characteristics were compared between the 2 groups. Psychometric instruments were used to evaluate QoL (EORTC QLQ‐C30 global health status and functional scales) and symptoms (FACT‐B). The correlation between the change in the QLQ‐C30 total score and the sum of FACT‐B symptom scores (TOTS) for the different domains was analyzed to identify domains more severely affected by treatment. P value < 0.05 was considered statistically significant. Results: In our sample, we identified a statistically significant negative correlation between breast cancer‐related QoL (global health status and functional scales) and the severity of the symptoms of breast cancer‐related symptoms. Analyzing the results from the CT + RT group, the QLQ‐C30 total score and TOTS decreased from baseline to 6 months in all of the domains. The baseline CT + RT group exhibited a clinically significant improvement in the quality of life and body functions. The FACT‐B symptoms decreased in most domains, with some improvement observed in physical well‐being and emotional well‐being. Conclusions: In conclusion, this study revealed that patients who underwent CT + RT experienced a decline in QoL and body functions and showed symptoms related to cancer and treatment. It is recommended to identify symptoms and provide appropriate interventions to maintain quality of life in breast cancer patients.

Background
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) testing is crucial for the early detection of HIV infection, which is the gateway to access HIV treatment and care. While the number of people living with HIV worldwide has decreased, many people still lack access to HIV testing, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. Community-based testing, which can be provided by non-clinical community members, has shown great potential in increasing the coverage of HIV testing in resource-limited settings. The effectiveness of community-based testing in Kazakhstan needs further research. This study aims to explore the perspectives of individuals who received a community-based HIV testing service (CBHTS) in Mangystau region of Kazakhstan.

Abstract:
Background: To investigate the relationship of 17β‐estradiol receptors (ERs) and androgen receptors (ARs) expression in the cervico‐vaginal mucosa of postmenopausal women having a hysteroscopy for hysteroscopic removal of intrauterine adhesion (IUA). Patients and Methods: This study included 30 healthy postmenopausal women having a hysteroscopy for IUA removal. The expression patterns and intensity of ERs and ARs were observed in the endometrium, myometrium and vaginal walls using the immunohistochemical staining method and evaluated. Results: The mean age of patients was 52.5 ± 5.7 years. The positive rate of ARs in the cervical mucosa, endometrium and myometrium was 80%, 0.7% and 53.3%, respectively. The expressions of ARs in the endometrium and myometrium were statistically less than those in the cervical mucosa (P=0.012, P=0.031). The positive rate of ERs in the cervical mucosa, endometrium and myometrium was 93.3%, 86.7% and 60%, respectively. There was no statistically significant difference in the expression of ERs between the cervical and endometrial tissues (P=0.380), and there was a statistical difference between the endometrium and myometrium (P=0.012). The AR‐positive rate of the uterine cavity in cases of mild to moderate adhesions was significantly lower than that in cases of severe adhesions (P=0.002) when the ER‐positive rate changed based on histological types. Conclusion: In postmenopausal females, the expression pattern of ERs and ARs presents the following in a descending order: endometrium, myometrium and cervical mucosa, and these findings will be helpful for the clinical diagnosis of IUA.

Abstract:
Background: Atelectasis due to bronchial asthma is a common postoperative complication during cardiac surgery. This study investigated the frequency and potential mechanism of atelectasis. Patients and methods: Seventy‐five patients were recruited during general anesthesia cardiac surgery with bronchial asthma, and 100 matched patients with general anesthesia cardiac surgery without bronchial asthma were selected as the control group. Patients were randomly divided into two groups, group A and B. The preoperative spirometry and pulmonary function were measured in all patients. At the end of the operation, arterial blood gas, lung ultrasound and chest radiography were observed and recorded. Results: There were no significant differences in sex, BMI, age and pulmonary function between groups A and B. Anesthesia induction time, intubation time, operation time and operation time did not show a statistical difference. The number of patients with PO4 < 1.4 mmol/L after tracheal intubation and operation in the Atelectasis group was significantly higher than that in the control group (P < 0.05). The number of patients with arterial PCO2 (pHPA) ≤ 35 mmHg in the atelectasis group was significantly higher than that in the control group (P < 0.05). An increase in PO4 and pHPA in the atelectasis group, which can effectively predict atelectasis, was also observed. Conclusion: Bronchial asthma is a risk factor for postoperative atelectasis, and a decrease in pHPA and an increase in pCO2 are risk factors for atelectasis. We hope that these results can provide a basis for the diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of atelectasis in bronchial asthma patients.

Abstract:
Background: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) require careful clinical management. Objectives: We aimed to clarify the effect of a nurse‐based telephone coaching on patients with COPD. Methods: The randomized, open‐labelled controlled trial was conducted at Kobe University Hospital from March 2013 to March 2015. Of participants with COPD, 47 were assigned to test and 53 to control group. The test group was given individualised telephone coaching, while the control group did not receive any phone calls. The mean of intervention duration was 4.9 months (range 1.0 month ‐ 12.5 months). Results: The total number of hospitalizations due to COPD and the average number of acute exacerbations per patient year were significantly reduced in the test group, however. The number of days missed from home was significantly reduced in the test group. On the contrary, there were no statistically significant differences in other outcomes. Conclusion: A nurse‐based telephone coaching may contribute to COPD management in the future.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The clinical use of fluoroscopic navigation catheter during percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is increasingly being used to facilitate the success of PCI. It remains unclear whether fluoroscopic navigation catheters actually improve procedural outcomes, and many questions remain regarding their use. This study aimed to provide an overview of the evidence on the safety and efficacy of fluoroscopic navigation catheters during PCI. METHODS: Comprehensive systematic literature searches were performed on the efficacy of fluoroscopic navigation catheter‐assisted PCI compared with conventional PCI. MEDLINE, EMBASE and Cochrane Library databases were searched for randomized controlled trials (RCTs) of fluoroscopic navigation catheters. The main outcome measures were procedural success, major complication rates, procedural duration, radiation dose and cardiac enzyme levels. Data were extracted from each article and outcomes were analyzed and tabulated. RESULTS: A total of six studies, including 646 (n=318; fluoroscopy group, n=328) patients, were included. Fluoroscopy‐guided PCI was associated with higher procedural success (six of six studies; relative risk [RR] 1.30, 95% CI 1.11‐1.53, P=0.001) than conventional PCI. Major complication rates and radiation exposure between the two groups were similar. There were no significant differences in periprocedural myocardial infarction and mortality. CONCLUSION: The preliminary evidence shows improved procedural success when a fluoroscopic navigation catheter is used. Further research is needed to ascertain its impact on long‐term outcomes and to determine other clinical benefits of this technology.

Background. In patients with obesity, bariatric surgery may provide weight loss with beneficial metabolic effects. Bariatric surgery is usually preceded by a 6‐month preparation period of diet counseling and weight loss. Despite the efficacy of behavioral treatment options for obesity, most of these patients will need pharmacological intervention to achieve targeted weight loss targets. This multicenter, prospective, randomized, and non‐blinded pilot study wants to investigate the safety, tolerability and effectiveness of orlistat during the preparation period in morbidly obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery. Methods. 140 subjects were randomized to receive 120 mg orlistat thrice a day (OD) or placebo OD for 6 months prior to bariatric surgery. Exclusion criteria were: diabetes, hyperlipidemia, renal failure, liver failure, active gastrinoma, gastrointestinal conditions or drug taking that increases gastric acid secretion, pregnancy, lactation, chronic pancreatitis and uncontrolled seizure disorder. The primary outcome measures were weight loss, glycometabolic profile, blood pressure, liver function and adverse effects of orlistat. INTRODUCTION

Crohn’s disease (CD) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the gastrointestinal tract with a substantial impact on patient’s physical and mental health, quality of life, and healthcare system-related costs.1 Current treatment options for CD are divided into three groups based on disease extent: small bowel disease, colonic disease, and ileo-colonic disease.2 The majority of patients with CD (80-90%) have ileal and/or ileo-colonic disease, which is often associated with strictures, fistulas, abscesses, and intestinal obstruction that require urgent surgical intervention.3 Surgical resection is a common treatment option for CD and involves removing the affected segment of intestine, rejoining the healthy bowel ends, and, if necessary, anastomosing the bowel with an ileostomy or colostomy.4 However, surgical resection is associated with potential risks, including adhesion formation, bowel obstruction, and recurrence of the disease.5 Thus, it is crucial to accurately assess the disease severity and activity before surgery to ensure optimal treatment.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The objective of this study is to assess the efficacy and effectiveness, as well as the long-term safety of the IOPHANE system, composed of a vaginal pessary, after 30 weeks of wear, in the treatment of post-menopausal urogenital atrophy.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study is a single-center, monocentric, Phase IV study designed to evaluate the impact of vaginal pessary placed with the IOPHANE system during 6 months on urogenital atrophy and its symptoms compared to a control group which will receive the same pessary without the IOPHANE system. A total of 42 women will be included in this study and will be randomly placed within 2 separate groups. The 1st group will be treated for 6 months with a vaginal pessary placed with the IOPHANE system and the other group will be treated without it for the same period.The IOPHANE system will be placed through outpatient surgery to guarantee the safety of the vaginal pessary and its proper fit. It will then be possible to detect and control any possible risks of this procedure such as a vaginal infection. During the 6 months of follow-up, the pessary will be removed during a single visit by the physician at the follow-up visit.This study will investigate the efficacy and clinical efficacy of the IOPHANE system on women presenting with urogenital atrophy and their symptoms by evaluating anatomical, clinical and biological criteria, as well as symptoms and patient comfort.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
An increasing amount of studies suggest that regular physical activity is associated with better quality of life and lower anxiety levels in adults with asthma. A similar level of benefit may be achievable by participation in complementary activities such as yoga. However, the effect of yoga on symptom management remains unclear.

Detailed Description
-----------------
There is a strong overlap between yoga and physical activity. Both of these activities have been shown to have several beneficial effects on individuals with asthma, including reduced anxiety and improved quality of life. However, the effect of yoga on asthma symptoms control remains unclear, and high-quality research is required to support its use as an adjuvant therapy. The primary purpose of this study is to obtain preliminary information about whether yoga as such is associated with less severe asthma symptoms, and fewer asthma attacks, in adults. Study participants will be randomized to either a yoga group (study intervention), which will receive yoga training once per week by a yoga and movement therapy specialist or to an attention-matched control group (attention-matching) with the same training frequency but with different exercises. These groups will be followed for three months.

Official Title

The Effect of Yoga on Disease Severity and Quality of Life in Adults With Asthma

Background and Aims: This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of the addition of oral administration of curcumin‐piperine to an antihypertensive regimen on the prevalence of sleep apnoea syndrome (SAS). We performed a cross‐sectional study that comprised 100 adults with hypertension taking various antihypertensive medications. Methods: Patients were divided into a case group (oral administration of curcumin‐piperine for more than two months, n = 59) and a control group using the antihypertensive regimen without curcumin‐piperine (n = 41). Both groups were treated for six months, and the frequency of treatment was adjusted as necessary during the study period. The main outcome criteria were the prevalence of SAS in the two groups before and after treatment. Secondary outcome criteria included the changes in blood pressure and medication dosage before and after treatment. The SAS diagnostic criteria included (1) the number of times snoring occurred was >50/h and (2) the Oxygen Desaturation Index (ODI) was > 5/h. A statistical analysis of the data was performed using the t‐test, chi‐square test, Mann‐Whitney U test, or Fisher's exact probability test as appropriate. Results: The prevalence of SAS before treatment in case and control groups was 23.7% and 36.6%, respectively, with no statistical difference. However, the prevalence of SAS after treatment was significantly lower in the case group than the control group (25.4% vs. 34.1%, p = 0.008). In addition, the number of snoring events in the case group was significantly reduced compared to the control group (30.0 ± 25.2 vs. 42.2 ± 21.4, p = 0.018). Investigator Network to Advance Genomics (INGenuity)

Introduction
=================
The Investigator Network to Advance Genomics (INgenuity, www.ingenuity.org) is an initiative of the Genomic Investigation Network (GIN) to enable scientific discovery by establishing the framework for genomic and phenotypic testing of rare and intractable diseases. INgenuity provides research-quality diagnostic genomic and phenotyping services through coordinated networks of investigators. INgenuity partners with the National Human Genome Research Institute’s Electronic Infrastructure for Genomic (EIGEN) Medicine project, which seeks to define the clinical, operational, and scientific needs for a national distributed electronic health care infrastructure to support genomic medicine. INgenuity is a collaboration led by Duke University with a national advisory board and includes the development of research networks and the creation of an informatics infrastructure.

Funding

National Institutes of Health-National Human Genome Research Institute

Exclusion criteria are a key part of any clinical trial, helping to ensure the study data is of high quality and relevant to the intended study population. In this section, I will review the proposed exclusion criteria for the study and discuss their relevance and rationale. Here is an overview of the inclusion and exclusion criteria for the study:

Inclusion Criteria:
•	Participants aged 18 to 55 years old
•	Good health with no clinically relevant abnormalities
•	Voluntarily joins the study and signs an informed consent form
•	Has a body mass index (BMI) within the range of 19 to 26 kg/m2
•	No pregnancy plans and voluntarily takes effective contraception measures
•	Has not had fever or signs of infection in the past two weeks
•	No history of drug abuse or use of drugs of abuse

Exclusion Criteria:
•	Pregnant or lactating women
•	Individuals with medical history or current diseases/abnormalities that may interfere with the safety and efficacy evaluation of the drug
•	Individuals with positive results for infectious diseases
•	Individuals who have recently undergone surgery or are planning to undergo surgery
•	Individuals taking medication known to interfere with the pharmacokinetics or pharmacodynamics of the investigational drug

Inclusion Criteria Discussion:
The inclusion criteria ensure that the study participants meet the eligibility requirements for the study. The minimum and maximum age range of 18 to 55 years old is appropriate to include healthy individuals who are less likely to have age-related health issues and are at a stable stage of life where their health status is not likely to change significantly.
BMI within a range of 19-26 kg/m2 maintains consistency in study participants and minimizes the potential confounding factors that may impact the pharmacokinetics and tolerability of the investigational drug.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) aiming to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a home use 3L hand-held spinal pump in the management of low back pain (LBP). The spinal pump used in this study employs a pneumatic pump to discharge pressurized air into the subarachnoid space via a lumbar subarachnoid catheter and is usually managed in the outpatient clinic. It is a minimally invasive intervention and is often used for patients with complex and refractory LBP that has not responded to other forms of therapy. Home use of a 3L hand-held spinal pump is a new approach that involves educating the patient and caregiver to safely operate the pump at home. This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of this approach. The study will also evaluate patient outcomes, including pain reduction, functional improvement, and quality of life improvement. This study will enroll 30 subjects into the 3L hand-held spinal pump group and 30 subjects into the standard care control group. The follow-up duration for each subject will be 24 weeks. The study will be conducted in a university medical center in Thailand.

Official Title
-----------------
Efficacy and Safety of the 3L Hand-held Spinal Pump for Management of Low Back Pain: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Conditions

Low Back Pain

Intervention / Treatment

* Device: Three-liter hand-held spinal pump

Introduction:
Motor control is essential for human movement. One factor that affects the ability to move is the strength of muscle contractions. It has been shown that muscle strength is reduced during prolonged contraction, which is a concern for individuals who need to generate a large amount of force for extended periods to perform daily activities. Fatigue has been shown to have negative effects on performance, motivation, and cognitive function in young, healthy males. This is particularly important for athletes and individuals with neurological disorders who rely on muscle strength to perform specific tasks. Fatigue-related muscle weakness can result in injuries and reduced performance, which can lead to decreased quality of life and increased health care expenses. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effect of fatigue on isokinetic muscle strength and explosive strength in healthy young men. The study aims to assess the impact of fatigue on muscle strength and determine whether there is a correlation between muscle strength and performance after fatigue. This study will help us better understand the mechanisms underlying the decrease in muscle strength during fatigue and identify interventions to improve muscle strength and alleviate fatigue.
Objective:
The objective of this study is to evaluate the effect of fatigue on isokinetic muscle strength and explosive strength in healthy young men.
Inclusion Criteria:
The study will enroll 20 healthy young men between the ages of 18 and 35. The candidates will be free from any musculoskeletal or neurological conditions that may affect muscle function. Additionally, the study candidates will be free from any medical history that may affect performance. Candidates will be asked to refrain from any strenuous physical activity for at least 48 hours before the testing session.
Exclusion Criteria:
Exclusion criteria are musculoskeletal or neurological conditions, medical history that may affect performance, and engaging in strenuous physical activity within 48 hours of the testing session.
Study Design:
The study will be a cross-sectional study design with a pre-post design. It means that we will collect data from the subjects before and after the experimental intervention.

Abstract:
Objectives: To assess the efficacy and safety of a novel injectable product in treating erectile dysfunction (ED). Material and Methods: We conducted a randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled trial in 90 patients to compare the efficacy of 20 mg of compounded papaverine, 10 mg of Caverject® and 0.5 mg of Regitine® injection, with placebo injection in ED patients, and to evaluate the safety of these treatments. Main Outcome Measures: The primary outcome measure was the proportion of patients with a satisfactory erection, defined as a score of 7 or better on the Erectile Function Domain scale (EF‐ED) score  of the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF). Results: All participants received a total of four ‐ injections during each of eight weeks of the double‐blind trial period. The incidence of treatment‐related serious adverse events was similar across the three treatment groups (pneumonia, 1 in the papaverine group; angina and myocardial infarction, 1 with Caverject and placebo). Significant differences were observed between the three treatment groups: papaverine and placebo injections were significantly more effective than Caverject®  injections. The results of the EF‐E score in the papaverine group did not differ significantly from the placebo group; whereas the results in the Regitine® group were significantly better than those of the placebo group. Conclusions: Intracavernosal injections of 20 mg of compounded papaverine combined with 0.5 mg of Regitine® improved erectile function significantly more than 10 mg of Caverject® without increasing the risk of serious adverse events.

Abstract:
STUDY OBJECTIVES AND DESIGN: This randomized clinical study compared a wedge implant with a conventional 2‐implant overdenture.MATERIALS AND METHODS: Forty‐eight edentulous patients were prospectively enrolled, and randomized into 2 groups who were followed for 24 months. The control group received 2 conventional 13‐mm diameter implants, and the study group received 1 wedge implant. The conventional 13‐mm diameter implants were inserted 10 mm apart, while the wedge implant was placed 2 mm closer to the midline. The primary outcome was the marginal bone level after 24 months. Secondary outcomes included implant stability indices, quality of life measurements, and clinical scores.RESULTS: After 24 months, no statistically significant differences in marginal bone loss (‐0.09 + 0.17 mm and ‐0.09 + 0.21 mm; p = 0.99) and plaque index score (0.09 + 0.13 versus 0.09 + 0.17; p = 0.84) were observed between the 2 groups. There were no statistically significant differences in the implant stability indices or the Clinical Outcome Score.CONCLUSION: The wedge implant has shown promising results, comparable to a 2‐implant overdenture, and offers a potential alternative for edentulous patients. Our study was limited by its small sample size, which may have affected statistical significance. However, the wedge implant showed no difference in marginal bone level, plaque index, or Clinical Outcome Score compared to the conventional 2‐implant overdenture system..

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This prospective, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial will explore whether adjuvant therapy with a high concentration form of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) in the form of the commercially available product Peridex® is effective as prophylaxis against periodontitis. The study duration in the clinic will last 2-1/2 yrs. The duration of study participation is expected to be 4 years, but may be longer with the option of continuing if clinically indicated. Participants will be randomized into two groups, either a hydrogen peroxide 1% (HP®) study group or a placebo control group. HP® group: Participants in the HP® group will be instructed to use the HP® twice a day for 6 months during the initial 12 month study period (after which an individualized regimen will be determined after a clinical evaluation. Placebo control group: Participants in the placebo control group will be instructed to rinse with a similar tasting placebo daily for 6 months during the initial 12 month study period (following which HP® or placebo will be determined on a case- by-case basis for study retention ). A trained dental hygienist will measure gingival health at every participant's initial and final visit, 12 and 24 months later. Patients will be clinically assessed for attachment level and pocket probing depths at every visit and also receive an assessment of their medical history and dental records at baseline and follow-ups. Clinical data will be collected and recorded in a secure, HIPAA-compliant database. The primary endpoint of the study is to compare differences in gingival health between groups using PASI-C restoratively modified plaque index and gingival bleeding index (PASI-G) as measured by a Calibrated and certified Examiners at 12 and 24 months post-enrollment.

The study aimed to investigate the clinical significance of cardiac rehabilitation in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. 
Methods:
48 patients(35 men, 13 women) with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction from August 2017 to August 2020 in Wonju Severance Christian Hospital were studied. All patients visited a medical center at least once a year for routine follow-up after initial diagnosis. Patients without hospital admission related to heart failure, who participated in cardiac rehabilitation on at least one occasion during a follow-up period due to heart failure related symptoms such as dyspnea or fatigue, were considered as the CR group(n=25, 52.0%), whereas those who failed to participate in any CR program (did not receive any rehabilitation exercise) (n=23, 48.0%) were considered as the non-CR group.
The primary outcome measurement was the changes in 6-minute walking distance(6MWD) between the baseline and the end of the study. The 6MWT assessed symptomatic differences from dyspnea and fatigue, an objective measurement of exercise capacity, and clinical prognostication in patients with heart failure. Multivariate linear regression analysis was performed to investigate the independent impact of cardiac rehabilitation(CR) in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Temporary hypoglycemia is defined as glucose less than 70 mg/dl for a short period. Some patients with insulin-treated diabetes may experience hypoglycemia. This study is to investigate whether these patients have low levels of glucagon after hypoglycemia. The results from this study will help to develop better treatments and management strategies for hypoglycemia in patients with diabetes.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The investigators will be recruiting participants from the Clinic for Diabetes and Metabolism at Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC). Participants will receive intravenous glucose boluses in two sessions to achieve hypoglycemia, followed by an intravenous bolus of glucagon in one of the sessions to achieve normoglycemia. Glucagon and a cocktail of amino acids will be administered. The study will be composed of two phases: 1. Hypoglycemia testing with amino acids alone. 2. Normoglycemia testing with amino acids and glucagon. Subjects will not be told whether they are receiving glucagon.

Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease who were admitted to the intensive care unit of the University of Arizona Comprehensive Cancer Center for treatment related to lung cancer or metastatic cancer to the lung are being recruited for this study. The investigators wish to learn whether the use of noninvasive blood pressure cuff monitoring, in conjunction with intermittent boluses of opioid medications as needed for pain and opioid-like medications for sedation, is as safe and well tolerated as an invasive blood pressure catheter.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease who were admitted to the intensive care unit of the University of Arizona Comprehensive Cancer Center for treatment related to lung cancer or metastatic cancer to the lung are being recruited for this study. The investigators hypothesize that noninvasive blood pressure cuff monitoring, in conjunction with intermittent boluses of opioid medications as needed for pain and opioid-like medications for sedation, is as safe and well tolerated as an invasive blood pressure catheter. All patients in this study will be monitored with an arterial line. Patient characteristics including blood pressure, heart rate, temperature, pain, and sedation levels will be recorded every 15 minutes until they receive more than 20 mg morphine with or without 40 mg dexmedetomidine, at which time they will be followed out every 4 hours for 72 hours or until they are discharged from the intensive care unit, whichever comes first. Patient's comfort level with the placement of an arterial line rather than the use of a blood pressure cuff will also be assessed once.

C.1.3.2 Secondary objectives of the trial: To further explore the potential benefits of the study treatment, the secondary objectives will assess the impact of the analgesic intervention on additional outcomes, such as postoperative pain management, opioid consumption, recovery time, and patient satisfaction rates. The secondary objectives include:
• Pain intensity after surgery, as assessed using visual analog scale (VAS) scores for pain at rest and during movement.
• Opioid consumption after surgery, as measured by the total amount of opioids used within the first 24 hours postoperatively.
• Postoperative recovery time, measured by the time from surgery to the patient's discharge from the recovery room.
• Patient satisfaction rates, evaluated through patients' self-reported levels of satisfaction with pain management and their overall satisfaction with the surgery experience.
C.1.3.2 Secondary objectives of the trial (es): Explorar adicionales los beneficios potencios que habría el tratamiento, los objetivos secundarios de este ensayo evalúan el impacto del tratamiento analógico en otros resultados, tales como la gestión del dolor postoperatoria, el consumo de opioides, el tiempo de recuperación postoperatoria y las tasas de satisfacción del paciente. Los objetivos secundarios son:
• Valoración de la intensidad del dolor después de la cirugía, medida mediante puntuaciones en la escala visual analógica (EVA) de dolor en reposo y en movimiento.
• Consumo de opioidos después de la cirugía, medido en la cantidad total de opioides consumidos en las primeras 24 horas postoperatorias.
• Tiempo de recuperación después de la cirugía, medido en el tiempo transcurrido desde la intervención quirúrgica hasta el alta del servicio de recuperación postoperatoria.
