Abstract:
Introduction Vitamin A is a well‐known antioxidant and has protective effects against severe respiratory infections, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), an inflammatory respiratory manifestation of COVID‐19. Animal studies have shown promise for vitamin A in providing protective effects against the clinical manifestations of coronavirus infections. Several clinical trials in patients with vitamin A deficiency have demonstrated favourable effects of vitamin A at preventing mortality from pneumonia and sepsis, and a recent study showed a reduced need for mechanical ventilation in critically ill patients with vitamin A deficiency. This exploratory trial aims to assess the effect of vitamin A on patient survival and the incidence of mechanical ventilation in patients with COVID‐19.Methods and analysis This randomised, blinded, controlled clinical trial will recruit hospitalised patients who are confirmed to have COVID‐19. Patients who are aged over 18 years and have had COVID‐19 for at least two days will be randomised (1:1) to receive an intramuscular injection of 600 mg of vitamin A, 50 000 IU, or placebo once daily for up to two weeks or until discharge, if sooner. The primary endpoint will be a time‐to‐event analysis of mortality and a binary composite outcome of admission to the intensive care unit (ICU) or death. The two groups (vitamin A vs placebo) will be compared for differences in the primary endpoint (log‐rank test). Medical Research Council (MRC) social outcomes framework - Part 4

Abstract:
Rationale: A recent international consensus statement has introduced the Medical Research Council (MRC) social outcomes framework (SOF) as a method for measuring and reporting social outcomes in musculoskeletal trials, building on the International Consortium for Healthcare Outcomes Measurement (ICHOM) research in rheumatology. The consensus statement suggests that a subset of five "core" domains be used to facilitate comparisons between different interventions and settings. However, it has been suggested that, as with other measures such as health‐related quality of life (HRQoL), the degree to which 'core' domains are applicable across patient populations and settings is questionable. Methods: To investigate the breadth of applicability of the MRC SOF in musculoskeletal trials, and particularly in early arthritis (RA), a review of recent RA trials was performed retrospectively to highlight whether trials were using MRC SOF items or alternative social outcomes measures. The MRC SOF domains that comprise the five‐item core domain set were identified, and whether existing trials were measuring each domain was recorded. Furthermore, whether these trials were measuring the core domains exclusively or supplementing them with additional domains that a patient would consider of greater importance in the context of RA was recorded. Results: The review of all RA trials published between 2008 and 2019 identified nine trials that measured MRC SOF domains in early RA. Of these, eight were found to be measuring the core domain set exclusively, and one was found to be measuring the core domain set in conjunction with a broader set of domains. Conclusions: This study highlights the need for further consensus about the applicability and relevance of the MRC SOF in musculoskeletal trials. The use of a standardised set of core domains (for example, the five core domains of the MRC SOF) is encouraged as it will facilitate direct comparisons of studies. Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of tauroursodeoxycholic acid (TUDCA) administration on blood pressure (BP) reduction and heart rate (HR) decrease in patients with hypertension or tachycardia under anesthesia. Methods: In this randomized double‐blind clinical trial study; 65 patients were evaluated during elective lower abdominal surgery. The patients were randomly divided into two groups : TUDCA group and control group. Hemodynamic data (HR, non‐invasive BP) were recorded before and after induction, after incision and at the end of surgery. Results: There was a significant rise in the HR immediately after incision in patients under general anesthesia (P<0.001). TUDCA given in a dose of 8mg / kg had a significantly greater effect on HR reduction at this point in comparison with the control group (P<0.001). In terms of non‐invasive BP immediately after incision, the effect of TUDCA in comparison with the control group was less pronounced but significantly different (P=0.049). On the other hand, TUDCA reduced the HR at every post‐incision data collection point relative to the control group and was significantly different at the end of anesthesia (P<0.001). Conclusions: TUDCA could affect anesthesia‐induced hypertension through BP regulation as well as it can reduce anesthesia‐related tachycardia.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: There is concern that premenstrual symptoms (PMS) and premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) may contribute to suicide attempts due to the fluctuating effects of sex hormones on mood, cognition and behavior.AIMS: To test the hypothesis that menstrual cycle‐related mood changes are a risk factor for suicide attempts among adolescents.METHODS: Women aged 15‐19 years who had experienced a suicide attempt and a cohort without a suicide attempt were recruited for this prospective study between June 2006 to October 2007. A structured interview was used to elicit detailed psychiatric information including menstrual cycle history. A blood sample was collected at days 21‐28 to measure the serum concentration of sex hormones before and during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.RESULTS: Of the 169 women in the suicide attempt cohort, 84% had experienced a suicide attempt during menstruation. During their last suicide attempt, women in the suicide attempt group had increased anxiety (P=0.049), cognitive impairment (P=0.008) and dysphoria (P=0.002), when compared to women in the control group. In addition, serum estradiol concentration was positively correlated with negative symptoms (P=0.014) among women who had experienced a suicide attempt in the last menstrual cycle.CONCLUSION: The present study lends support to the hypothesis that hormonal changes during the menstrual cycle may contribute to the risk of suicide attempts, especially among adolescent girls with borderline personality or mood disorders.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study is a prospective, observational, multi-centre study to evaluate the safety and performance of an artificial intelligence (AI)-based system for diagnosing pulmonary fibrosis. Approximately 6,000 participants with suspected IPF from 90 participating sites in the United States will be enrolled in the study. The participants will undergo high-resolution CT (HRCT) with pulmonary function testing (PFT) and blood test as part of their routine clinical care, and the CT and PFT results will be analyzed using the AI-based system to provide a provisional diagnosis of IPF. The AI-based system will score the CT images in the order of certainty for the diagnosis of IPF based on machine learning using a large CT dataset labelled by trained radiologists. This study will last approximately 2 years.

Abstract:
Background: Pulmonary tuberculosis (PTB) is a common disease found in developing countries, including Malaysia. The diagnosis of PTB often relies on microbiological confirmation with the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M.tb) in sputum. Urine examination has been recommended in those with high pretest probabilities for PTB, but the accuracy of the urinary M.tb antigen (UMA) test has not been assessed in settings where the prevalence of PTB is high. In Malaysia, the prevalence of PTB is high (0.2‐14.2 %) in adult patients. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to prospectively evaluate the accuracy of the UMA test in a hospital setting in a high‐TB prevalence country. Methods: 246 patients suspected of smear‐positive PTB were enrolled over a four month period. The UMA test was performed on 239 urine samples, and the sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative likelihood ratios were calculated with mycobacteriology culture and smear microscopy as the reference standards. Results: The UMA test had a sensitivity of 71 % (95 % confidence interval (CI): 52‐85) for M.tb detection in adults and children with sputum smear positivity. The specificity of the UMA test was 100 %, and the positive and negative likelihood ratios were 16.2 and 0.3, respectively. However, the sensitivity of the UMA test in smear‐negative adults was only 47 % (95 % CI: 29‐67). Conclusion: The UMA test has low sensitivity in high‐prevalence settings. However, in a hospital setting where a high proportion of smear‐positive sputum is available, the specificity of the UMA test is high, and it may be useful for distinguishing true‐positive from negative urinary samples. # Researchers from Canada test if acupuncture is effective at decreasing pain in patients with knee osteoarthritis

This study aimed to evaluate the benefits of acupuncture for relieving pain in patients with knee osteoarthritis in Canada. The study included two groups of patients: those who received traditional acupuncture treatment and those who received sham acupuncture. The participants in the traditional acupuncture group received treatments on the same day every week for a total of twelve weeks. The participants in the sham acupuncture group received treatments on the same day every week for a total of four weeks. The researchers found that, compared to those in the sham acupuncture group, those in the traditional acupuncture group had reduced pain scores and improved quality of life. In addition, all of the participants in the study were able to participate in follow-ups because of the ease of delivering the treatment and the lack of side effects.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this project is to understand the effects of the current coronavirus pandemic on the quality of life in the elderly. Using the EQ-5D questionnaire, this project aims to evaluate and compare the quality of life of the elderly pre (before the onset of the coronavirus pandemic) and post (after the onset of the coronavirus pandemic) outbreaks in India.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The rapid spread of the novel coronavirus has spread a wave of fear and panic all over the world. The most affected age-group appears to be the elderly. With the elderly already burdened with health issues such as hypertension, heart failure and diabetes, not only are they more at risk of acquiring the disease, but also facing more physical and mental complications. The quarantine imposed to contain the spread of the disease has created an adverse impact on mental health in this age group, with the fear of COVID-19 leading to increased anxiety and reduced quality of life. This study aims to evaluate the reduction in quality of life in the elderly (60 years and older) during pre and post pandemic periods. The study will also evaluate the change in their quality of life as their understanding and awareness about the virus increases. The objectives of the present study are (1) to find out the percentage prevalence of the coronavirus before and during the pandemic among the elderly, (2) to determine the quality of life of the elderly before and during the coronavirus pandemic, and (3)to study the effect of awareness regarding COVID-19 on the quality of life of the elderly. The research will be carried out by employing an explanatory cross-sectional design with a mixed methods approach. Convenience sampling will be used to sample the elderly in nursing homes in Bengaluru. The study will be conducted in various nursing homes in various parts of Bengaluru. These nursing homes will be selected using a purposive sampling technique. For the quantitative part of the study, the data will be collected by filling out questionnaires. Abstract:
The pathology and pathophysiology of chronic pelvic pain (CPP) are poorly undertood. Frequently, the patient undergoes multiple surgical interventons with an unclear benefit, and the clinical results vary significantly. To this day, no biomarker can define the chronic pelvic pain syndrome. The treatment of CPP includes multidisciplinary treatment and surgical intervention. The most common surgical indications include uterro‐vaginal adhesions, uteroidenomas, pelvic endometriosis, adnexal pathologies. In a systematic literature review, we wanted to assess the effectiveness of surgical treatment on the subjective (pain) and objective (return to normal activity) outcomes of patients affected with CPP. A systematic review of the literature was performed on PubMed, Embase, and the Cochrane database with an initial search query of surgical management and CPP. The literature was reviewed independently by two authors, two additional articles were obtained from references within the articles selected. Two reviews published in 2008 assessed the impact of uterus‐vaginal adhesiolysis, uteroidenoma removal, and hysterectomy in CPP. These reviews found that in 16% of women, pelvic pain improved after surgery. According to a recent prospective randomized controlled study (2019), the only significant finding was that the quality of sex life was improved more by hysterectomy than by adhesiolysis. A randomised control trial (2019) of laparoscopic salpingectomy resulted in significant improvement of pain. All the studies reviewed have limitations due to the lack of control intervention and the lack of objective parameters for assessing pain and quality of life. There are few studies assessing the effects of surgical treatment in women with CPP. More well‐controlled clinical trials are needed to accurately assess the clinical benefits of this treatment.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The proposed project is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, longitudinal observational study involving subjects with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. The proposed project plans to enroll 500 subjects with non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and randomly assign them to either the Intervention or the Control group prior to receiving a fatty liver screening test (or bi-contour liver ultrasound). Subjects in the Intervention group will receive 2000 mg eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) for 36 weeks, while subjects in the Control group will receive an identical placebo for the same duration. The aim of this study is to investigate changes in liver function and histological characteristics over time. Specifically, the proposed project will determine whether EPA supplementation can improve liver steatosis, inflammation, and fibrosis. The study also aims to determine if EPA, in combination with a liver healthy lifestyle, can improve liver health.

A Preliminary Study to Investigate the Impact of Eicosapentaenoic Acid on Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatits in a Real-world Sample

Brief Summary
-----------------
Obesity-induced insulin resistance (IR) is a widespread disease associated with reduced quality of life and increased risk of type 2 diabetes, heart disease, and cancer. It can increase the size of liver cells, causing fatty liver disease (steatosis, fibrosis, cirrhosis). This condition in its most severe form (cirrhosis) is associated with 1.5 million deaths annually. We will investigate whether metformin, which is known to improve insulin sensitivity, can improve liver fat in obese, insulin-resistant humans. Our goal is to establish whether metformin will favorably alter liver and skeletal muscle metabolism in subjects with type 2 diabetes or IR, including the possibility that it will decrease liver fat. The overarching principle behind this trial is to determine how an insulin-sensitizing agent affects liver metabolism in humans. In addition, we will attempt to identify molecular mechanisms by which metformin alters liver metabolism (e.g. fatty acid metabolism, protein metabolism, etc.)

Abstract:
Cerebellar Tumors (CTs) are relatively rare, often highly aggressive and treatment options remain extremely limited. We report a series of 80 CTs arising in adult patients, operated during a 7‐year period at the University Hospital of Bordeaux. The aim of this study was to describe our recent surgical results, with a special emphasis on the prognostic relevance of some tumor histological parameters, including the assessment of the number of histological sections analyzed. We defined 6 prognostic groups, that reflected our results and prognostic values. Based on our analysis, the number of histological sections is one of the most important prognostic factors. However, a good survival outcome is possible for patients having an entirely and well‐performed histological sampling (p < 0.001), and the number of sections is more directly correlated with the probability of making a specific histological diagnosis than the number of blocks. Furthermore, we report an improved overall and relapse‐free survival compared to the literature for both high‐grade (GBM, GBM‐like, anaplastic malignant glioma) and low‐grade (malignant mixed glioma, anaplastic astrocytoma) tumors when analyzing the treatment achieved for each patient. Finally, we discuss the relevance of each surgical approach for the patients presenting with a benign cerebellar lesion.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary objective of this study is to assess the efficacy of recombinant human interleukin-1 receptor antagonist (IL-1ra) in patients with the sickle disease in improving the quality of life and reducing the need for intravenous analgesic and frequency of acute chest syndrome during six months.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Acute and chronic pain are common and debilitating complications of sickle disease. Pain causes a high-quality of life impairment, poor performance, high school drop-out, decreased function, depression, and a lower likelihood of successful employment. Intravenous analgesics are often the only intervention for acute pain, but there has not been a demonstrable improvement in pain management and reduction of morbidity, particularly in patients in pain crisis. There is a major unmet need in the field of pain management in this population. A single-center, randomized, double blinded, placebo controlled trial in 100 children and adolescents to evaluate analgesic efficacy, quality of life, pain duration, incidence of hospital stay due to acute chest syndrome, and adverse effects of the recombinant human interleukin-1 receptor antagonist (IL-1ra, anakinra).

Official Title
-----------------
A Single-Center, Randomized, Double Blinded, Placebo Controlled Study of the Analgesic Efficacy & Safety of Interleukin-1 Receptor Antagonist on Pain Severity Measure, Quality of Life, Hospitalizations, and Episodes of Acute Chest Syndrome in Children and Adolescents With Sickle Cell Disease

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of MTX and NAC in controlling postoperative pain in total joint arthroplasty

Detailed Description
-----------------
Postoperative pain after hip and knee replacement is a major problem. It can cause pain and other discomforts, prolonged hospital stays and rehabilitation times, and decrease patient satisfaction and quality of life. It is also a risk factor for thromboembolism and infection. Current treatment may not be effective in some patients, and there is a need for more effective methods to control pain. N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is an antioxidant that has been shown to reduce inflammation and pain. Methotrexate (MTX) is a commonly used drug for pain management. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of MTX and NAC in controlling postoperative pain in patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty. The study is a double-blind, randomized, controlled trial that will compare the impact of MTX and NAC versus NAC alone on the amount of pain medication used and the pain score after surgery. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either MTX and NAC or only NAC. Participants and pain assessors will be blinded to treatment allocation. To explore the possible mechanism of action, serum levels of inflammatory cytokines will be measured before and after surgery.

Official Title
-----------------
The Effect of Combined Administration of Methotrexate and N-acetylcysteine on Postoperative Pain Management After Total Joint Arthroplasty

Conditions
-----------------
Osteoarthritis

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Drug: Methotrexate
* Drug: NAC

Abstract:
The purpose of this study is to identify the most acceptable delivery system of acupuncture for patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) in terms of fatigue. The sample comprised participants with MS aged over 18 who are currently experiencing moderate fatigue and live in the Vancouver area (Canada). We will use a randomized, between‐subjects design to compare the effects of four acupuncture delivery systems: real acupuncture, sham acupuncture, auricular acupuncture, and electroacupuncture applied for 20 minutes each, over the course of five consecutive treatment sessions (total treatment time = 2.5 hours). Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the four groups using block randomization, and be assessed at four time points: immediately postintervention, 24 hours postintervention, 2 weeks post interventions, and 6 weeks postinterventions. The primary outcome is patient‐rated fatigue according to a fatigue impact scale and a pain impact scale. Data will be analyzed using ANOVA with repeated measures and Bonferroni's post‐hoc test to determine which group had the minimal significant change at the four time points. Results from this study will identify the most acceptable delivery system of acupuncture for MS patients in terms of fatigue and determine whether acupuncture reduces fatigue and pain in patients with MS. This finding will be used to develop a more effective acupuncture intervention to treat MS‐related fatigue. Furthermore, it will also inform future researchers on how to design acupuncture interventions to reduce fatigue.

However, there is limited direct evidence for this and thus a controlled clinical study is required to evaluate efficacy and safety.METHODS: This study is a double-blinded two-period placebo-controlled cross-over study of l-carnitine and placebo in 40 patients receiving ADT. Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this project was to create an online intervention for caregivers (n=103) caring for people with ALS. A total of 103 ALS caregivers were recruited to test the intervention during the intervention program and a questionnaire, the Family Quality-of-Life Questionnaire, was administered at baseline and post-intervention to participants. The results showed that there were significant improvements in caregivers' quality of life after the intervention. This project was part of a larger project focusing on the care environment for ALS caregivers and their partners.

Inclusion Criteria:
1. Age 18 years or above.
2. Tooth with significant symptoms or with root apex bone tissue destruction that cannot be treated by non-surgical methods.
3. The affected tooth is either an anterior tooth or a premolar.
4. The size of the lesion during preoperative cone beam computed tomography (CBCT) coronal acquisition is at least 6 mm but not more than 12 mm.
5. The affected tooth has undergone successful root canal treatment.
6. CBCT shows intact lingual side bone plate in the apical region, with only buccal alveolar bone defect present.
7. Good oral hygiene and compliance with medical instructions.

Exclusion Criteria:
1. Severe periodontal destruction, with over 1/3 of the root length absorbed by alveolar bone.
2. CBCT shows root fracture or root canal perforation.
3. After root apex surgery, crown-root ratio ≤1:1.
4. Presence of surgical contraindications, systemic and local factors that affect wound healing.
5. Pregnant women and females planning to conceive within the next two years.

In the patient flow diagram, patients will be placed in the allocated groups through sampling numbers, which are listed in a sealed, opaque envelope.

Intervention 2: Control group: Traditional oral feeding will be delayed. Oral feeding will be initiated when surgical drainage fluid has been produced for at least 24 hours, the patient's hemodynamic stability is stable, the patient has bowel sounds, gas discharge, and normal serum creatinine, amylase/or lipase, and white blood cell count.

Rationale and aims: Acute postoperative pain is one of the most unpleasant sequelae of breast biopsies, although it may not be completely avoided. Various studies have suggested that the use of regional anesthetic techniques (e.g., local infusion anesthesia (ILA), pectoral nerve block (PNSB), and paravertebral thoracic anesthesia (PVTA) ) can effectively reduce postoperative pain in patients undergoing breast biopsies. However, the analgesic effect of these techniques remains unknown in patients undergoing biopsy under ultrasound-guided local anesthesia (USGIA). This study aims to explore the analgesic effect of these techniques in patients undergoing biopsy under USGIA. Further, this study aims to determine the best technique for relieving pain post-USGIA. Methods: This study will be conducted as a prospective, randomized, assessor-blinded, comparative study. A total of 60 adult patients aged 20-60 years, each scheduled for USGIA breast biopsy, will be allocated into one of the four study groups using the block randomization method: USGIA local anesthesia group (group A), USGIA ILA group (group B), USGIA PNSB group (group C), and USGIA PVTA group (group D). Each group undergoes a different analgesic technique. The primary outcome is the numerical rating scale (NRS) score for pain at rest one day after surgery, while the key secondary outcome is the postoperative NRS score. Moreover, pain at rest and during movement, the opioid analgesic consumption, the incidence of nausea and vomiting, and other adverse events will also be evaluated. Results: The results will be analyzed using the intention-to-treat (ITT) and per-protocol (PP) analyses, and the significance level will be set at p<0.05. Discussion: This study will be the first to explore the effectiveness of various analgesic techniques in patients undergoing breast biops

Our study aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of BCMA‐based CAR‐T‐cells in newly diagnosed, relapsed refractory, and high risk MM. Methods & Design All patients who had progressed after at least three lines of therapy, received autologous transplant or not, or achieved only a partial response to their last line of therapy were eligible. Ethical issues: The study adheres to all national and international regulations regarding the protection of human subjects. The study will be conducted in accordance with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice Guidelines. All patients will sign informed consent before participating in the study, and there is no direct compensation for participation. Study limitations: The study size is small, and the results may not be representative of the general population with MM. In addition, the study is conducted at a single center, which may limit the generalizability of the findings.

Abstract:
Background: The use of immunotherapy in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) has been under investigation, with the aim of improving outcomes for patients. Hypothesis: This study evaluated the effectiveness of the combination of CD47 blockade and PD‐1 checkpoint blockade in patients with relapsed and progressing CLL. Methods: This prospective, open‐label, multicenter, randomized phase I study enrolled patients with relapsed and progressive CLL after at least 1 line of treatment. Eligible patients were randomly assigned to two groups, group A received the CD47 bispecific antibody, SGN‐403, and group B received SGN‐403 in combination with nivolumab. Safety was assessed by the incidence of treatment‐related adverse events (TRAEs). Effectiveness was assessed using standard clinical criteria for response to therapy, such as the European CLL Criteria (EUCLL) 2018. Results: A total of 18 participants were enrolled and randomly assigned to group A (n = 10) or group B (n = 8). Median follow‐up was 9.5 months. Median time to treatment failure was 4.8 months in group A and 1.1 months in group B. The overall response rate was 70% in group A and 75% in group B. Progression‐free survival was 65.5% in group A and 68.9% in group B. Grade ≥3 adverse events were reported in 16.7% (n = 9/54) of patients in group A, and in 14.3% (n = 4/28) of patients in group B, including hyperlipidemia, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. Abstract:
AIM: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of allograft osteochondral implantation procedure for treatment osteoarthritis of knee.METHODS: This prospective, unblinded, randomized, controlled trial included 53 patients with degenerative arthritis of the knee, who were randomized to receive either an autograft osteochondral implant from the tibia or an intraarticular injection of frozen allograft to the knee. Follow‐up included clinical examination, range of motion evaluation, pain assessment, and radiographic assessment.RESULTS: Patients in the experimental group had reduced pain and improved functional scores post‐surgery compared with pre‐surgery scores. The range of motion of the affected knee was significantly less in patients from the experimental group (p = .039) compared with patients from the control group. The knee radiographs showed that the implanted allograft tissue was intact and the joint space was greater than in the control group, while no osteoarthritic changes were seen in the allograft group. The experimental group had a postoperative complication rate of 20% compared with 5.9% in the control group.CONCLUSION: Intraarticular injection of frozen allograft to the knee is safe and effective for improvement in pain, while also slowing progression of knee joint degradation.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Inadequate glycemic control, which is mainly characterized by hyperglycemia, is a common problem in diabetic patients undergoing major surgery under general anesthesia. This study aims to investigate the effects of pramlintide therapy on glycemic control and postoperative prognosis in diabetic patients undergoing esophageal surgery under general anesthesia.

Detailed Description
-----------------
A prospective, randomized, control study was conducted in Diabetic Patients who underwent major esophageal surgery under general anesthesia in our hospital from January 2021 to December 2021. Patients were randomly divided into experimental group and control group (1:1). 40 Patients in the experimental group were treated with pramlintide (0.375 μg/kg, subcutaneous bolus, within 30 minutes before induction of general anesthesia; 40 Patients in the control group were treated with the same dose of saline placebo. Changes in intraoperative and postoperative blood glucose and insulin doses were observed. Adverse reactions and the incidence of postoperative complications were analyzed. This work has prospectively registered at www.chictr.org.cn (Number: ChiCTR2100049832).

Effects of Pramlintide on Glycemic Control and Postoperative Prognosis in Diabetic patients Undergoing Major Esophageal Surgery Under General Anesthesia

Great! Let's discuss the exclusion criteria then. These criteria are designed to ensure the study focuses on the intended population and avoids potential confounding factors or risks.

The first exclusion criterion is the exclusion of patients with APL (acute promyelocytic leukemia), specifically the M3 subtype of AML. This helps maintain the focus on a more homogeneous population and prevents potential confounding factors related to this specific subtype. Any questions about this criterion?

The next exclusion criterion is the exclusion of patients with active CNS (central nervous system) leukemia. Patients with active CNS involvement may require different treatment approaches, so excluding them helps maintain the focus on the intended study population. Any questions about this criterion?

The third criterion states that patients who have received previous treatment with CDK8 and/or CDK19-targeted therapy are excluded. This ensures that the study evaluates the safety and efficacy of the combination therapy without potential interactions or confounding effects from prior targeted treatments. Any questions about this criterion?

The next criterion is the exclusion of patients who have undergone major surgery within 28 days prior to the first dose of the study drug. Recent major surgery may impact a patient's ability to tolerate the study treatment or affect the interpretation of safety and efficacy outcomes. Any questions about this criterion?

The fifth criterion is the exclusion of patients who have undergone hematopoietic stem cell transplant within 120 days prior to the first dose of the study drug. Recent stem cell transplant may influence the patient's immune system and response to the study treatment, potentially confounding the results. Any questions about this criterion?

The sixth criterion is the exclusion of currently pregnant or breastfeeding individuals. Excluding pregnant or breastfeeding women is essential for the safety of both the mother and the fetus or infant. Any questions about this criterion?

=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine if the use of a mindfulness-based intervention will help to reduce stress levels, increase mindfulness, and increase gratitude for Black youth who are experiencing homelessness. Specifically, the study aims to examine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of this intervention in this population. The study hypothesis is that the intervention will lead to positive outcomes for the participants. The study will also explore if there are any barriers or challenges that may prevent the use of the intervention. Additionally, the study will investigate whether the intervention is effective in reducing stress and increasing mindfulness in this population.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The proposed pilot study will aim to answer these research questions by recruiting 40 Black youth aged 16-24 who are experiencing homelessness in the Boston area. The research questions are as follows: 1) Are all components of the intervention feasible? 2) Is the intervention effective in improving outcomes such as stress, mindfulness, and gratitude in Black youth who are experiencing homelessness after completing all 4 sessions? The research team will conduct focus groups and interviews with participants after completing the intervention to evaluate its feasibility and effectiveness in improving outcomes. The study team will analyze the data from the focus groups and interviews using a qualitative analysis approach. The results of the study will provide valuable insights into the feasibility and effectiveness of this intervention in helping Black youth who are experiencing homelessness. The findings will help inform future research and practice in this area.

Abstract:
Introduction: Cognitive behavioral couples therapy (CBCT) includes principles of mindfulness and acceptance in the treatment of sexual difficulties in heterosexual couples. To expand on the effectiveness of CBCT, which has been assessed in a heteronormative model, it is crucial to adapt the treatment protocol to address the unique concerns of same‐sex couples. Method: The primary aim is to examine the effectiveness of the new protocol, designed to be gender neutral, among same‐sex couples compared to traditional CBCT. Twenty same‐sex couples will be randomly allocated to either a CBCT group or a CBCT+ mindfulness and acceptance (CBCT+MA) group. All participants will complete baseline measures of psychosocial variables, and then will participate in six 105‐minutes weekly sessions of CBCT or CBCT+MA. The primary outcome measures will be psychosocial outcomes: the Dyadic Adjustment Scale (DAS) and the Mindfulness‐Acceptance Scale (MAS). We will also explore possible mediating effect of attachment style (Attach Scale for Adult Romantic Relationships) through structural equation modeling (SEM). Hypotheses: We expect the new treatment protocol to be more effective against traditional CBCT among same‐sex couples, with higher attachment style predicting more positive psychosocial adjustment. Results: If recruitment proves challenging, a larger sample may be necessary or we may need to revise our recruitment strategy. However, we expect our protocol to be effective in improving psychosocial adjustment and reducing sexual difficulties. Discussion: The study has the potential to develop an evidence‐based CBT protocol, which could be used in future studies with larger sample sizes.

Objective: To compare the incidence of in‐hospital mortality after acute type B aortic dissection (ATBAD), perioperative period, and late surgical intervention between type I and the subtype of type II requiring an aortic intervention. Method: We retrospectively analyzed 501 consecutive patients with ATBAD from Jan 1990 to Sep 2017 in a high‐volume tertiary referral center. We classified ATBAD cases based on a standardized definition and classified type I into the true and false forms based on the anatomical location of the entry tear. The true type I was defined as involving the intima of the descending aorta and false type I was defined as a non‐true one. Results: Among the 501 patients, 158 patients (31.5%) died before or at discharge. The overall incidence of in‐hospital mortality was 31.5% (158/501). The incidence of in‐hospital mortality of the true type I and false type I was 25.4% (37/146) and 27.1% (54/200) (P = 0.649). Among 224 patients with perioperative period, the incidence of in‐hospital mortality was 35.4% (24/68) in the true type I and 36.8% (26/71) in the false type I (P = 0.968). In 94 patients with late surgical intervention, the incidences of in‐hospital mortality following true type I, false type I, and type II (n = 87) were 52.1%, 35.3%, and 3.4%, respectively. Brief Summary

Hepatic Steatosis is a major public health concern, with increasing mortality rates in adults and children. Childhood obesity has been increasing worldwide in recent years. One of the main factors associated with hepatic steatosis is obesity, which is due to a change in eating habits. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease can also be associated with other diseases such as type 2 diabetes, hypertension or dyslipidemia. In addition, hepatic steatosis may precede the diagnosis of type 2 diabetes or arterial hypertension. Current treatments include maintaining a healthy lifestyle, exercise and nutrition. However, due to the growing prevalence of hepatic steatosis and obesity, prevention programs with nutritional education are required. In Mexico, hepatic steatosis is estimated at 11% of the population, obesity at 34% and diabetes at 13.7% in children and adolescents. It has recently been published that the prevalence of hepatic steatosis in adolescents is 15% and the prevalence of obesity is 26.4%. Although children who receive nutritional education have a decreased incidence of obesity, diabetes and hepatic steatosis, there are no published studies, specifically on nutritional education with low-calorie sugars (D-allulose) and low glycemic index. Previously, our research group observed that nutritional education including low-calorie D-allulose can impact the glycemic profile and anthropometric markers in adult obese individuals. Objective: To investigate the effect of nutritional education on the anthropometric, lipid and glycemic profile in obese adolescents with hepatic steatosis using low-calorie D-allulose. Methodology: Participants will be randomized into two groups.

Abstract:
Introduction: There is a need for research on the safety and efficacy of D‐allulose in children who were born to women who were not pregnant when the drugs were taken. Objective: To investigate the safety and efficacy of D‐allulose in children born to women who were not pregnant when the drugs were taken. Methods: A single‐center, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, randomized, parallel, dose‐escalation trial in a total of 12 children was performed. Children were randomly allocated to receive one of four dose levels (15, 30, 60, or 90 mg per kg per day) of D‐allulose or placebo. A 14‐day washout period was followed by a second 14‐day active‐drug period or continued dosing during the intervention phase. The primary outcome was the change in serum amylase levels from baseline to week 12 and the secondary outcomes included changes in serum lipids, liver function, hormonal levels, and urinary microalbumin/creatinine ratio. Results: No serious adverse events were observed during the intervention period, and the number of adverse events showed no consistent trend. Significant differences in changes in the serum lipids and glucose levels between D‐allulose groups and the placebo group were observed. The serum levels of glucose, cholesterol, and triglyceride in the 30mg/kg/day group significantly decreased after the intervention compared to baseline. Conclusion: D‐allulose is a safe and well‐tolerated drug with potential efficacy in children. Large, long‐term, and multi‐center trials are needed to fully evaluate the safety and efficacy of D‐allulose in children born to women who were not pregnant when the drugs were taken.

-----------------
This study aims to examine the effects of a high-fat meal on postprandial serum concentrations of free fatty acids (FFAs) and glucose, and the role of D-allulose (N-allulose, an isomer of sucrose) as a dietary fat absorption inhibitor. The investigators hypothesize that D-allulose does not affect the rate at which FFAs or glucose are absorbed from a postprandial high fat meal. To study the effects of D-allulose on postprandial fat absorption and blood glucose levels, D-allulose will be added to a test meal in a randomized, crossover design. This study will determine the effects of D-allulose on postprandial lipemia and glucosuria. Secondary endpoints will include the effects of D-allulose on gastrointestinal transit and stool hardness.

Abstract:
OBJECTIVES: To define the evolution of symptoms following bulking agent injections (BI) in patients with urinary incontinence (UI).BACKGROUND: BI has been shown to be an effective treatment for mild‐to‐moderate UI due to urodynamic or non‐urodynamic stress urinary incontinence (SUI), but there is little data concerning its long term follow up and the time course of its effect, in women with SUI only.MATERIALS AND METHODS: The data in this retrospective study comes from a prospective cohort study of patients undergoing BI for stress SUI. A total of 131 consecutive patients underwent BI at a tertiary referral center. Demographic data and results of urodynamic studies pre‐ and post BI were recorded. At the same time, the patients were asked to complete the validated Urinary Distress Inventory (UDI‐6) and the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire‐Urinary (ICIQ‐UI).RESULTS: Only 102 eligible patients completed both pre‐ and post‐operative UDIs and ICIQ‐UI questionnaires. Mean follow up was 24 months. No difference was noted between the UDIs and the ICIQ‐UI pre‐ and post‐injection. Median number of injections received was 1. There appeared to be an initial improvement in the majority of patients with a decline in the benefits at 18 months. The degree of improvement in patients with no symptoms pre‐treatment was greater than those with mild or moderate symptoms pre‐treatment.CONCLUSIONS: The benefits of BI were greatest in patients with mild or no stress symptoms. The improvement was not maintained over 18 months of follow up, but the number of patients with symptoms were low. It is concluded that BI is still a good treatment option, with the majority of women feeling a benefit and no complications incurred.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to find out whether an alternative treatment to amniocentesis could offer a safer and more cost-effective way to test for fetal chromosome abnormalities. To compare the safety and diagnostic performance of chorionic villus sampling (CVS) and amniocentesis, as a non-invasive screen, in determining chromosomal abnormalities. To collect information on maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality rates associated with these procedures.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to verify the efficacy of the alternative therapy in detecting trisomy 21: the non-invasive screen consists of blood and urine samples analyzed in a laboratory using molecular technology. If chromosomal abnormalities are found, CVS will be offered as an alternative pre-natal screening test. If no abnormality is found, the study will continue without any further screening test.

Consecutive patients attending OPD surgical clinic at UGMC on weekly basis were reviewed. Their demographic details  are documented alongside all the laboratory investigations. Before surgery in the operating room, 1.0 mL of venous blood was drawn for PCT measurement from each study participant. Serum samples were centrifuged and the serum stored at -70°C until use. The study aimed to describe patients' clinical manifestations, laboratory features, disease severity, and outcome; and the efficacy of 2 widely used drugs.Methods: This was a prospective, observational study of patients admitted to Tororo regional Referral Hospital in eastern Uganda from January to December 2021 with suspected viral hemorrhage fever. We diagnosed a confirmed case by reverse transcription‐polymerase chain reaction testing for Rift Valley fever virus. The severity of the disease was assessed using case fatalities (CF) and survival rates (SR%). Results: We diagnosed 79 patients, with a case fatality rate of 29%. The mean age was 30.65 years (range 10 months‐69 years). Most cases had at least one bleeding episode, including gastrointestinal bleeding in 29.1% and menorrhagia in 7.6% of females. The most common clinical symptoms were fever (98.7%), headache (86.1%), jaundice (84.8%), and vomiting (81.0%). Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to perform a retrospective medical records audit of patients treated and diagnosed with moderate to severe cystic fibrosis (CF) between January 2011 and December 2018, as part of quality assurance and service improvement activities. Twenty patients, undergoing treatment with Kalydeco (ivacaftor), were enrolled in this case note audit, which reviewed treatment outcomes since starting treatment with Kalydeco. The outcome measures were frequency, types, and reasons for missed appointments, as well as reasons for missed medication doses. We identified 444 missed appointments and 984 missed doses for a total 1428 missed doses. 25% of clinic‐appointments were missed, and 43% of medication doses were missed. The mean (SD) number of missed appointments per patient was 21.9 (16.7), with a mean (SD) duration of 29.4 (26.5) h. The main reasons for clinically missed appointments were unspecified illness/general unwellness, and a high volume of missed appointments being attributed to patient's own admission to hospital. The main reasons for patient‐reported missed doses were lost tablets, forgetting to take tablets and vomiting. The audit findings underlined the need to implement strategies to improve adherence, in order to reduce the risk of poor adherence.

Purpose: The purpose of this systematic review was to assess the evidence for the effectiveness of vitamin D supplementation in patients with diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs). Method: A literature search was carried out in the following databases through June 2021: CENTRAL (Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials), PubMed, SCOPUS, EmBase, Wanfang data, China National Knowledge Infrastructure, and China Science and Technology Journal Database. Primary and secondary outcome measures were assessed in randomized controlled trials (RCTs) that determined changes at the end of treatment (EOT), or the difference between baseline and EOT, or changes at each measurement of two or more time points after randomization using meta‐analysis techniques. A standardized mean difference (SMD) was defined when comparing continuous variables, and risk ratio (RR) was utilized for dichotomous variables at a threshold of P < 0.05. Results: Six RCTs (total 519 subjects) were identified. Most of the studies included patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and/or DFUs. The mean age was close to 65 years, and over two‐thirds (69.4%) were female. Participants with a short duration of the DFU showed a 58% reduction in the EOT relative risk of complete wound healing (RR = 0.42, CI 95% 0.20‐0.89) in comparison with the nonvitamin D group, but there was no significant difference, with a RR of 1.30 (CI 95% 0.92‐1.85) in the vitamin D group compared with the control group (RR = 0.68, CI 95% 0.44‐1.05). Brief Summary

The purpose of this study is to assess the potential clinical utility of implantable sacral neuromodulation as a treatment option for moderate to severe motor paralysis of the lower extremities in patients with Cerebrovascular Disease(CVA) by investigating the effects of sacral neuromodulation compared to no sacral neuromodulation for lower extremity joint spasm. Detailed Description
-----------------
CVA is a disease caused by a sudden interruption of blood supply in the brain due to blockage of blood vessels or rupture of blood vessels in the brain; It is generally divided into cerebral hemorrhage and cerebral infarction according to the characteristics of brain damage. The clinical symptoms vary according to the location of the damage and the degree of the damage. 2% of all ischemic stroke cases have lower extremity deficits, and spasticity, muscle atrophy, and other related symptoms affect the patient's activities of daily living and activities of daily living quality, which are the main problems that patients suffer from. Among them, spasticity that occurs in the lower limbs is a disease in which the hyperreflexic state of the skeletal muscle is observed due to the disorder of the nervous system. It is one of the factors that hinder the restoration of mobility in patients with lower limb disorders. In cases of focal motor paralysis, the muscles of the lower extremities, including the gastrocnemius muscle, quadriceps muscle, and hamstring muscle, are paralyzed in a flaccid manner. In addition, spasticity increases as the tone of the muscle is restored due to muscle spasm. Joints are fixed in a flexion posture to increase the pressure on the joint and limit its mobility. Abstract:
Purpose: The coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid19) has caused a global pandemic in 2019. The rapid spread of the disease and the limited treatment options have led to a high mortality rate. This study aimed to assess the mortality rate and risk factors associated with Covid19 pneumonia in Khorasan Razavi and the effect of early invasive ventilation on mortality in Covid19‐intensive care unit (ICU) patients. Methods: According to the available records of Covid19‐inpatients from 7 hospitals belonging to the Khorasan Razavi Medical Sciences University in Iran, 305 patients were randomly selected and then randomly assigned to two groups of intervention and control. In the intervention group, invasive ventilation was performed immediately when patients presented with hypoxia, whereas patients in the control group were given high‐flow nasal catheter (HFNC) during the initial 72 h. The outcome measure chosen for evaluation in terms of statistical significance was between‐group mortality rates. Results: The mortality rate among patients who underwent invasive ventilation was 14.86%, whereas the mortality rate among those who underwent HFNC was 29.22%. The 72‐hour mortality rate was significantly lower in patients receiving invasive ventilation than in the HFNC group (P<0.001). The risk factors, including hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and obesity, were similar in the intervention and the control groups. Conclusions: The mortality rate in critically ill Covid19 patients is high. Early and effective ventilation has been associated with a lower mortality rate and may result in fewer ICU deaths.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to compare the efficacy of aliskiren in patients with hypertension resistant or refractory to thiazides when amlodipine is also added to the treatment regimen. Patients who have controlled blood pressure by conventional three anti-hypertensive therapy are recruited. Three months after a run-in period during which their medications are not modified, each patient starts taking aliskiren for 6 months. Then aliskiren is compared to placebo for an additional 6 months in a double-blind and crossover manner.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to compare the efficacy of aliskiren in patients with hypertension resistant or refractory to thiazides when amlodipine is also added to the treatment regimen. Patients who have controlled blood pressure by conventional three anti-hypertensive therapy are recruited. Three months after a run-in period during which their medications are not modified, each patient starts taking aliskiren for 6 months. Then aliskiren is compared to placebo for an additional 6 months in a double-blind and crossover manner. Aliskiren is an orally active direct renin inhibitor. It has a once-daily dosing that allows patients to take the drug as soon as they wake up, with a low number of pills per day.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Although the standard treatments for HCC are successful in preventing cancer recurrence, the treatment efficacy is not satisfactory. The tumor thrombus of HCC has the characteristics of strong invasiveness, rapid spread and fast growing. Therefore, to find a novel, effective and reliable treatment for HCC would be meaningful. Currently, radiofrequency thermal therapy has been used with good efficacy in the treatment of small-sized hepatocellular carcinomas and has been widely used in clinical, but this method has some shortcomings, such as being difficult to get the expected curative effect in huge-sized hepatocellular carcinomas, and so on. The new idea of using PVA nano-bubble (PNB) in combination with cryosurgery has been tried in animal experiments. In comparison of other targeted anti-tumor therapies, PVA nano-bubble (PNB) plays its own role in the treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma, which is a new idea and method that has not been widely used in the clinical treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma. PVA nanobubble has the unique advantage of being harmless to normal tissue without hemorrhagic transformation and its safety and feasibility have no safety concerns, as well as minimal adverse reaction in patients with high recurrence rate. In conclusion, PVA nano-bubble (PNB) + cryosurgery can provide an approach for preventing the recurrence of HCC after liver resection, which has important clinical significance in improving the prognosis.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is one of the most frequent causes of cancer related death throughout the world. Approximately 50-75% of patients with HCC are unsuitable for surgical resection at the time of diagnosis mainly due to advanced tumor stage at diagnosis. Abstract:
Objective: To analyze and describe the phenotypic characteristics and activity of leukocyte‐platelet aggregates (LPAs) in patients suspected of having heparin‐induced thrombocytopenia syndrome (HIT). Study design: Prospective, case‐control, observational study. Patients and methods: Fifteen patients with HIT syndrome who were diagnosed at our hospital via anti‐platelet factor 4 (PF4)‐heparin antibodies were included in the study. They were classified as HIT type II or III. Nineteen HIT‐negative patients and 19 healthy controls were included. Blood samples were obtained from patients at admission and after HIT treatment via standard procedures. Blood sample results were analyzed using FlowCAST and analyzed in terms of size, pattern, surface markers and activity of LPAs. Results: HIT LPAs (75%) were observed more often in HIT type II patients than in healthy volunteers or patients with HIT type III (25%). Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of 600 mg/d of the probiotic strain LGG (Lactobacillus rhamnosus strain GG; ATCC 53103) in maintaining pregnancy.METHODS: This single‐blind, randomized, placebo‐controlled, multicenter study enrolled healthy pregnant women at 15‐18 weeks of gestation. Subjects received either 600 mg/d of L. rhamnosus strain GG or placebo until the baby was delivered. Primary endpoints were the rate of premature births and mean gestational age at birth. Secondary endpoints included the rates of infection, intrauterine growth retardation, and newborn characteristics.RESULTS: A total of 154 eligible women were enrolled, 67 in each group. Compliance was > 90%. Neither group differed significantly by race, parity, or medical history. A total of 9 spontaneous preterm births occurred, 4 in the LGG group (9.0%) and 5 in the placebo group (8.63%), and no differences in premature birth rates were noted by race, parity, medical history, and baseline characteristics. Pregnancy complications such as hypertension, chorioamnionitis, hemolysis, etc., were not significantly different between the two groups. No difference in the mean gestational age at birth was documented. There were no significant treatment‐related adverse events.CONCLUSION: Daily intake of 600 mg/d of the LGG probiotic strain during pregnancy did not affect the risk of preterm births or other pregnancy outcomes in this study.

Aim: Identify and investigate the genetic drivers of PBC associated with a high risk of biliary cancer, and evaluate their potential as therapeutic targets.  Background and rationale: Over one third of patients with primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) progress to develop biliary cancer (BC) with only an estimated 3 years survival. PBC is a chronic autoimmune disease leading to progressive fibrosis and destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts. Over 90% of BC in PBC are of an intrahepatic type with a high cholangiocarcinoma (CCA) component. Elevated risk of BC in PBC is associated with several clinical, serological, radiological, and histological characteristics. Previous GWAS identified single nucleotide variants associated with risk of BC in PBC as well as liver fibrosis. However, these risk factors only captured a small proportion of the genetic contribution of BC risk in PBC, suggesting that additional genetic factors remain to be discovered. To this end, we assembled a large consortium of 10 UK referral centres and several centres in Europe. Our proposed study aims to: (i) extend the identification of genetic markers associated with risk of BC in PBC; (ii) identify the functional role of the associated genes; (iii) determine the mechanisms by which these genes induce BC risk; (iv) discover novel druggable targets in PBC. Lidocaine Patches for Perioperative Pain

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to prove that Lidocaine patches are safe to use, and to describe their effect in children undergoing elective inguinal hernia repair

Detailed Description
-----------------
The Lidocaine adhesive patch is used by various medical specialties such as anesthesia, cardiology, neurology and wound healing. In a pilot study carried out at the CPHMC pediatric pain unit, we found that the application of an unstudied Lidocaine Patch under general anesthesia in children during surgery was a safe and effective method of pain management without hemodynamic or neurological effects. We would like to continue using the patches as a part of our standard anesthetic procedure in pediatric inguinal hernia repair to further evaluate their safety and efficacy.

Post market clinical follow up: the SUPREMAT1 and SUPREMAT2 clinical program:
Abstract:
In order to improve efficacy and tolerability over currently marketed corticosteroid implants such as Trigratrix®, and to allow shorter administration of the drug, a new generation corticosteroid (CS) implant named Durellis® was developed, containing the same active ingredients as Trigratrix® but now incorporated into a new poly (DL‐lactide‐co‐glycolide) (PLGA) biodegradable polymer with a longer half‐life in the body and, therefore, with slow‐release capability leading to a lower CS release rate. Both SUPREMAT1 (NCT02116377) and SUPREMAT2 (NCT02609268), randomized, double‐blind, multicenter studies, are currently underway to assess the efficacy, tolerability, and safety of Durellis® (Durosant®), after implantation in the medial and/or lateral carpal tunnel, in order to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of Durosant® for the treatment of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). In SUPREMAT1, Durosant® is implanted as a single intra‐operative dose and the patient is assessed up to 6months, while in SUPREMAT2, the implant is administered as half dose implants per each side with a second re‐injection. The primary outcome measures of the SUPREMAT1 and 2 studies are the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire (BCTQ), symptom bother rating, and CTS‐Related Localized Symptom Score (CTS‐RLSS) at treatment Day (T0) and up to 6months. Secondary outcome measures include: the Michigan Hand Questionnaire‐Carpal Tunnel Module (MHQ‐CTCM), physician assessments, health‐related quality of life, grip strength, sensory nerve conduction velocity (NCS), and electrodiagnostic (EDX) measurements.

Abstract:
Background: Pregabalin use has grown significantly in recent years, increasing the potential for medication misuse and substance use disorder. This study aimed to assess the prevalence of and associated factors with pregabalin consumption in a population receiving treatment for substance use disorder. Methods: We conducted an observational study on 150 patients admitted for the treatment of substance use disorder. All patients were screened for pregabalin consumption at admission. Clinical and demographic data were collected and analyzed to identify associated factors. Results: The overall proportion of pregabalin use was 43.3% (65 of 150 individuals). In Multivariate analysis; having a diagnosis of depression (OR 4.08, CI [1.62‐9.76], p 0.003) and using other benzodiazepines (Odds ratio: 3.68, CI [1.30‐10.46], p 0.01) were identified as the predictors of pregabalin use. Having a prescription for pregabalin was strongly and positively associated with pregabalin use (OR 47.3, CI [22.84‐98.33], p < 0.001). Conclusion: Among patients treated for drug addiction, a significant proportion of patients used pregabalin at the time of admission. These cases are an indication of increasing pregabalin misuse which demands closer monitoring and regulation of use. Furthermore, depressive symptoms and other benzodiazepine use were correlated with pregabalin use and should be closely evaluated. 2023 Elsevier Ltd

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
One type of toothpaste widely utilized in dentistry to date, known as the CPP-ACP (Casein Phosphopeptide-amorphous calcium phosphate) system, can strengthen the enamel with help from fluoride. CPP-ACP technology has been developed in the 1980s and is used in many commercial toothpastes. The most commonly used CPP-ACP material is called Recaldent™. CPP-ACP is a biologically active protein-based compound derived from milk. CPP-ACP releases Ca, P and phosphoproteins from the protein. CPP-ACP has the ability to incorporate saliva calcium into the outer surface of the demineralized enamel crystal and bind this calcium ion in the crystal. CPP-ACP and fluoride is often used in dentistry for remineralization therapy. However, this approach has limitations. For example, some of the CPP-ACP molecules penetrate the teeth, and others do not. Moreover, they may be less effective when a toothbrush is not available or when a person does not know exactly where the demineralized tooth is. The authors propose to develop a new, non-invasive tooth remineralization therapy. The authors believe that this therapy is better because instead of coating the tooth surface, we can deliver the active agent directly to the demineralized areas using toothbrush and/or chewing gum delivery methods. The aim of the present study is to investigate a new material, chitosan-coated gold nanoshells (CNGS) for tooth remineralization therapy. Nanoshells show promising oral care benefits when combined with other treatments. It has been shown that CPP-ACP and chitosan work synergistically to promote the remineralization of enamel. Abstract:
In this meta‐analysis, we sought to examine the efficacy and safety of low‐energy shock wave therapy (SWT; 0.03 mJ/mm2) combined with exercise therapy for patellofemoral pain syndrome management. PubMed, Embase, Web of Science, and the Cochrane Library were searched from January 1, 2006, to January 1, 2018, with "patellofemoral pain syndrome," "low energy shock wave therapy," "exercise therapy," and "randomized controlled trial" as key search words. Seven randomized controlled trials involving 274 patients were included in the final meta‐analysis. The data from individual studies showed that SWT combined with exercise therapy significantly decreased the pain numeric rating scale (p<0.01) and improved WOMAC physical function (p<0.05) and Lysholm knee score (p<0.05) in patients. In addition, the combined treatment significantly improved the KOOS function subscale score (p<0.05), Patellar Pain (p<0.05), and VAS‐knee (p<0.05) in patients. This meta‐analysis suggested that the combined use of SWT and exercise therapy may be more effective than exercise therapy alone in reducing pain and improving functional outcomes in patients with patellofemoral pain syndrome. However, the therapeutic effects may vary by intervention duration. Hence, a larger sample size is required to further validate the results.

Abstract:
Introduction: The prevalence of major depressive disorder (MDD) in children and adolescents is increasing and may lead to a cascade of psychiatric disorders in the future. We set out to examine the characteristics and outcomes during 2 years of psychosocial therapy treatment among children and adolescents diagnosed with MDD, their parents, and teachers. Methods: We recruited participants aged 7–17, with parent and teacher evaluation of a depressive episode according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM‐5). Participants received weekly group therapy treatment for 2 years. Patients rated depression severity using the Children's Depression Inventory (CDI). Results: Three hundred forty‐three participants completed the study and were included in this analysis. The mean age was 12.5 years and 60% were girls. Their mean CDI score was 44.0. Of the 343 participants, 14.9% met criteria for persistent severe depression after 2 years of treatment, and 65.2% met criteria for a depression‐free state. Teachers rated the average CDI score the highest, followed by children and parents (P < 0.05). Conclusions: The severity of depression was consistently lower in patients than caregivers. Children with persistent severe MDD over 2 years of treatment should be considered at higher risk for a cascade of psychiatric disorders.

OBJECTIVE: To compare the long‐term efficacy and safety of single‐bundle phacoemulsification through a clear corneal self‐sealing microincision with bimanual femtosecond laser‐assisted phacoaspiration through a 4‐mm central incision.DESIGN: Interventional randomized prospective case series study.PARTICIPANTS: Thirty patients underwent the surgery for cataract extraction.METHODS: Subjects were randomly chosen to receive femtosecond laser (FSL) assisted clear corneal self‐sealing microincision phacoemulsification (CCI, Group‐A) with or without the implantation of a multifocal intraocular lens (IOL) using monofocal IOL or multifocal IOL (Group‐B) versus conventional bimanual phacoemulsification through a 4‐mm clear corneal central incision.RESULTS: There was no difference in the best corrected visual acuity at every followup visit, intraocular pressure and endothelial cell count. The average grade of the incision wound healing at 6‐weeks was 1.46 ± 0.68 in Group‐A and 1.38 ± 0.62 in Group‐B (P = 0.072).CONCLUSIONS: Femtosecond laser‐assisted clear corneal self‐sealing microincision phacoemulsification (FSL‐CCI) is a promising procedure for cataract surgery with favorable refractive, surgical, and postoperative outcomes compared to conventional clear corneal self‐sealing microincision bimanual phacoemulsification with an equivalent small corneal incision.

Abstract:
Background: Radiation therapy (RT) has been used to control symptoms of locally advanced or metastatic bone metastases (BM) since the late 19th century.1 The advent of modern radiotherapy techniques, namely intensity modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) and stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT), has led to better local control rates than conventional radiotherapy. Moreover, the rapid introduction of IMRT and SBRT has resulted in limited data available to compare these newer techniques with each other. Material and Methods: A systematic review of the literature was conducted using PubMed. The search strategy was comprehensive and focused on randomized trials (RCT) and high‐level observational studies only. Results: Overall, 17 articles were reviewed, and 5 RCTs met our criteria for inclusion. This review demonstrates the superior local control rates of IMRT compared to conventional RT as well as the benefit of SBRT over IMRT. Furthermore, it shows that IMRT delivers a better overall survival than conventional RT despite the use of higher doses. However, there is currently no evidence showing significant improvement in OS with the use of SBRT in the setting of palliative RT. Conclusion: This is a robust systematic review of high‐level literature in the use of IMRT and SBRT showing that, regardless of technique, IMRT and SBRT have similar efficacy in the treatment of painful BM. Moreover, the use of IMRT delivers a better rate of local control while maintaining local toxicity, especially with the addition of gaiters. However, there is a lack of high‐level evidence showing a clear survival benefit of both techniques over one another. Randomized trials with appropriate study designs and adequate statistical powering should be conducted to better characterize the benefits of these local treatment methods. Abstract:
Objective: To investigate the prevalence of depression and suicide ideation and the association with sleep disturbance among Chinese adults. Methods: A nationwide random population survey was conducted among 23,291 community‐dwelling adults of ≥ 18 years of age. Mental disorders were measured using the Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI). Depression was ascertained by the 12‐item short version of the Geriatric Depression Scale (short‐GDS‐12), and suicide ideation was ascertained by the suicide‐related item (SQ5) derived from the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ). Sleep disturbance was assessed using the Sleep Subscale of the Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scale (DASS‐21). Multinomial and ordinal logistic regressions were used to examine the associations between sleep disturbance and depression/suicide ideation. Results: Depression was present in 814 (3.5%) participants, and suicide ideation was present in 482 (2.1%) participants. The multinomial logistic regression showed that poor sleep quality was independently associated with depression and suicide ideation [adjusted odds ratio (OR) = 1.28, 95% confidence interval (CI) = 1.10‐1.48; adjusted OR = 1.31, 95% CI = 1.11‐1.55, respectively]. The ordinal regression analysis further showed that participants with greater severity of sleep disturbance had higher odds of having severe/very severe depression compared with those without sleep disturbance (adjusted OR = 1.70, 95% CI = 1.45‐2.00), even after adjusting for all potential confounders. 1. Introduction
The aging population, comorbidities, and technological advancements have led to a shift towards less invasive treatments for heart valve replacement
.
Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI) has emerged as a less invasive alternative to surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR) for patients with severe aortic stenosis
.
It has been observed that TAVI, compared to SAVR, is associated with:
(i)  
higher rates of in-hospital and 30-day mortality
(ii) 
shorter lengths of hospital stay
 (iii)
lower rates of stroke and acute kidney injury
, improved short-term and long-term outcomes
, and improved quality of life
.
Although the risks and benefits of TAVI compared to SAVR have been studied extensively, there is some controversy regarding the long-term outcomes of TAVI
.
Some studies have shown that TAVI is associated with higher rates of re-hospitalization in the long term
, while others have shown no significant difference in re-hospitalization rates between the two procedures
.
It is important to note that the follow-up duration has been relatively short in most studies examining TAVI outcomes, and there is a lack of data on the long-term health outcomes of TAVI compared to SAVR
.
We can address some of the issues raised in the existing literature by conducting a study with a long-term follow-up duration.
 We propose:
(i)  
Recruiting patients from a population-based cohort, which will allow for a more diverse population and reduce selection bias
(ii) 
Using a prospective design, which will enable us to collect comprehensive data on patients' long-term health outcomes
(iii) 
Conducting a randomized controlled trial, which will provide high-quality evidence on the effectiveness of TAVI compared to SAVR

Abstract:
Purpose: To compare the effect of thermal ablation (TA) versus surgical resection (SR) on survival and cost effectiveness in patients with early‐stage HCC. Patients and Methods: A retrospective cohort study used data from the National Cancer Database for 89,099 patients (41,949 TA and 47,150 SR) who presented with non‐metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma between 2012 and 2017. The primary outcome was overall survival (OS) with secondary outcomes of mortality, morbidity, and cost‐effectiveness. Kaplan–Meier survival curves were used to estimate overall survival and time to next treatment. A cost‐effectiveness analysis (CEA) was conducted from the perspective of US healthcare payers. Results: The median age was 68 (range 32–89). TA and SR were similar in terms of sex (62.8% vs 60.6%, p=0.004). Compared to women (HR: 7.5, p<0.001), TA was performed on more White patients (87.2% vs 85.2%, p<0.001). For White patients, TA was associated with OS compared to SR (HR: 0.75, p<0.001) while for non‐White patients, there was no difference in OS. Overall, treatment was associated with OS regardless of patient race. Conclusion: Although there was no statistically significant difference in mortality rates between patients who underwent TA and those who underwent SR, these 2 strategies were associated with significant differences in OS and morbidity rates among White vs non‐White patients. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study is to explore the characteristics of the patients who are referred to the cardiothoracic surgery department of the University of Utah and how many of them require surgery and how many are turned back to a non-surgical center.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be a retrospective chart review of 200 cases from January 2014 to October 2017. The aim is to review the patient's charts to answer the following questions: How many and what kind of patients were seen by cardiologists in the region? How many of them were referred to the cardiothoracic surgeons here at this institute? How many required surgery and how many were turned back to their cardiologists for further therapy? What is the reason behind turning them back? These questions will be answered by a data acquisition form containing: personal demographics, relevant medical history including relevant cardiovascular history and symptoms. We will also compare the time from the referral to the day of the operation.

Official Title
-----------------
The Reason Behind the Referrals to the Cardiothoracic Surgeon From Referring Center

Conditions
-----------------
Congenital Heart Disease, Heart Failure, Mitral Valve Disease, Tricuspid Valve Disease

Participation Criteria
=================
Eligibility Criteria
-----------------
Inclusion Criteria: The study will be a retrospective chart review of 200 cases from January 2014 to October 2017. All cases that were referred to the cardiothoracic surgery department and operated on or followed up will be included in the study. Exclusion Criteria: 1) Cases which referred in 2006-2007 was not included in the study. 2) Only cases that are operated on and followed up at this department will be included in the study. 3) Cases that were turned back for further management (medical management or cardiothoracic surgery) without coming back to follow up at the U of U hospital. 4) Cases that are not appropriate for the surgery will be excluded. 5) Cases with incorrect recordings. 6) Cases that were operated on in another center

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study aims to determine whether an early implementation of telemonitoring system will have an effect on patients' quality of life score. This pilot project uses telemonitoring and telecoaching to treat the chronic condition. The project begins as soon as the patient leaves the hospital after the intervention.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The main objective of the pilot test is to establish the feasibility and acceptability of the T2TM System, implemented for a period of 4 months, as a post-hospitalization follow-up monitoring tool. The study will focus primarily on the acceptance of home blood pressure monitoring and telemonitoring by the patients as well as their perceptions of T2TM System. The patients will be asked to complete the World Health Organization Quality of Life-100 (WHOQOL-100) questionnaire at the beginning of the study and at the end of the study. The study will be conducted over 18 months and will involve a total of 75 patients.

Feasibility and Acceptability of the T2TM System for Chronic Health Conditions
