This approach involves using the patient's own cells to treat their cancer. The cells used for this study are immune cells known as dendritic cells. Dendritic cells are found in the immune system and help the body to fight infection. They are one of the body's defences against cancer. 

Dendritic cells can be made from a patient's own immune cells. They can then be activated to make them better at fighting cancer. They are also given a substance called granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF). This helps them grow and mature. This process is known as ex vivo expansion. This means that the cells are grown outside of the body in a laboratory. 

After the dendritic cells have been activated and expanded, they are injected back into the patient. The idea is that these activated and expanded dendritic cells will help to fight the patient's cancer. Additionally, the GM-CSF stimulates the production of antiviral and anti-tumour substances, which may help to boost the immune system. 

This approach has already been successful in treating a variety of different cancers, including melanoma, lymphoma, and leukaemia. However, there is still a lot of research needed to determine the optimal way to use DC-GM-CSF therapy in treating prostate cancer. In this study, we will evaluate the safety and efficacy of this therapy in patients with prostate cancer.

We will also use a variety of advanced imaging and laboratory techniques to better understand how the dendritic cells interact with the patient's immune system. This information will help us to improve the design and delivery of future DC-GM-CSF therapies. 

Overall, this study will provide valuable information about the use of DC-GM-CSF therapy in the treatment of prostate cancer. We hope that this approach will lead to new and effective treatments for this disease. 

If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to contact us. 

Thank you for your interest in this research study.

Abstract:
Objective: The aim of this study was to estimate the incidence of acute pancreatitis in patients operated for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Summary Background Data: Postoperative acute pancreatitis is a well‐known complication after laparoscopic cholecystectomy. However, some authors consider the association between pancreas traction and the appearance of this complication. Methods: In a prospective study conducted at a single hospital over a 6‐year period we studied a group of 1522 patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy in which all patients underwent the same standard technique, including traction of the duodenopancreatic loop and subhepatic cholecystectomy. All the patients had been monitored postoperatively for at least 5 days while the clinical, laboratory and imaging features for the early diagnosis of acute pancreatitis were documented. Results: Postoperative acute pancreatitis was confirmed in two patients (1.3%) and it was severe in one. Conclusions: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is safe and free from postoperative acute pancreatitis.

Abstract:
Background: This study was designed to determine and compare the effects of 1% propofol and 1% propofol‐based remifentanil bolus‐infusion on hemodynamic stability and recovery of spontaneous ventilation after induction of anesthesia in ASA physical status I‐III patients scheduled for upper abdominal or head and neck surgery. Methods: Ninety patients were allocated randomly into two groups according to the anesthetic induction techniques used. Group P (n=45) was inducted with propofol and group R (n=45) with propofol‐based remifentanil bolus‐infusion. Hemodynamic changes, recovery of spontaneous ventilation (SO295%) defined as SO 95% and the need for atropine for postoperative bradycardia were compared between the two groups. Results: SO295% was 7.2±3.1 minutes in group P and 5.1±3.3 minutes in group R (p=0.02); the time in which the minimum heart rate was reached was 40.2±26.1 seconds in group P and 3.5±2.0 seconds in group R (p=0.03). Conclusion: In conclusion, it appears that the 1% bolus‐infusion of propofol plus remifentanil provides a greater hemodynamic stability and faster recovery of spontaneous ventilation than 1% propofol alone.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients with chronic pancreatitis are often treated endoscopically (endoscopic ultrasound-guided drainage for the treatment for pseudocyst, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)/papillotomy for the management of obstructive jaundice, endoscopic pancreatic sphincterotomy for pain management). Although these therapies are commonly used, their long-term outcomes are relatively unknown. To help assess the long-term outcomes of interventional endoscopic techniques for chronic pancreatitis, investigators have organized the North America Pancreatic Study Group (NAPSG) Registry. The NAPSG Registry is an ongoing research study that will follow patients with chronic pancreatitis who have undergone endoscopic interventions at approximately 30 medical centers across the United States. The purpose of this study is to explore the long-term clinical and radiologic outcomes of chronic pancreatitis, to determine when complications related to chronic pancreatitis develop, to identify risk factors that may contribute to their development, and to evaluate the efficacy of endoscopic interventions in the management of chronic pancreatitis and related complications.

Abstract:
Introduction: Although endoscopic ultrasound‐ guided transgastric endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (EUS‐Guided ERC) has been widely used for many years, there are few reports on EUS‐Guided ERC with large duodenal diverticulum (DD) cases. Herein, we first review 5 cases of EUS‐Guided ERC with large DDs. Case Presentation: For five patients, 26–38 year old (mean age, 30.3 years old) with DD and cholangitis, Ercp was performed by the EUS‐Guided method with DDs ranging in size between 5.8cm to 6.7cm. There was no intraoperative complication, such as bleeding and perforation. No patient developed pancreatitis after treatment, and no patient had DD or cholangitis recurrence during follow‐up. Discussion: The present study demonstrated that EUS‐Guided ERC had high safety and efficacy when performed for patients with large DDs. The procedure was well tolerated; however, it was still associated with a learning curve. Therefore, well training and understanding of relevant anatomy and technical skills (including fluoroscopy and pancreatic duct cannulation) are important for a safe and effective technique. Conclusions: For patients with DDs, careful preprocedural imaging and accurate diagnosis of the anatomy are necessary. EUS‐Guided ERC and pancreatic sphincterotomy can effectively deal with cholangitis, which offers a new method of treating refractory cholangitis, improving the prognosis of patients, and reducing the incidence of cholangitis recurrence.

The management of patients with HER2‐positive breast cancer continues to evolve rapidly in the era of immunotherapy and PARP inhibitors. Recent literature has shown that a subset of patients with HER2‐positive breast cancer and germline BRCA mutation may be candidates for systemic therapy in addition to neo‐adjuvant chemotherapy and/or HER2 therapy. In this study, the authors assessed outcomes of patients with HER‐positive breast cancer who were not candidates for PARP inhibitors but had germline BRCA mutations. The authors identified 88 patients who received sequential dual checkpoint inhibitors (n=21) and then an anti‐HER2 agent (n=55), or who received either dual or single checkpoint inhibitors (n=12) with HER2‐targeted therapy (n=9 and n=3, respectively). With a median follow‐up of 32.2 months, 7‐year outcomes included an invasive disease‐free survival (IDFS) rate of 67.9%, recurrence‐free survival rate of 69.8%, and distant recurrence‐free survival rate of 66.5%. Compared with previous studies, the authors observed a higher proportion of lymph node‐negative patients and lower proportion of those with visceral disease. The authors found that pathological complete response (pCR) rates after neoadjuvant chemotherapy in patients receiving sequential dual checkpoint inhibitors and anti‐HER2 therapy were 80% for the breast and 97% for the axilla. Overall, the authors found that high rates of pCR were observed with this regimen, but this remains to be seen in randomized studies. Abstract:
Background: Endometrial carcinoma is the most common gynecological cancer in developed countries, and the incidence is increasing each year. Immunohistochemistry plays a crucial role in determining the prognosis of endometrial carcinoma patients. A comprehensive understanding of the role of immunohistochemistry in prognosis can help in better stratification of patients and identifying potential new prognostic markers. Objective: The current study aims to investigate the role of immunohistochemistry in predicting prognosis in endometrial carcinoma patients. Methods: We will include patients aged 36- 72 years, with a previous diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma between 2015 and 2021 at the Xianlin Hospital in Nanjing, China. The patients will undergo immunohistochemistry analysis to assess the expression of biomarkers such as p53, ERO1, ER, and p‐ERK1/2. The data will be analyzed using appropriate statistical methods to evaluate the relationship between biomarker expression and prognosis. Results: Our preliminary study showed that immunohistochemistry analysis of biomarkers such as p53, ERO1, ER, and p‐ERK1/2 can help in predicting prognosis in endometrial carcinoma patients. Abstract:
BACKGROUND: To investigate the effect of a 2‐year exercise program on the cognitive function of patients with ischemic heart disease (IHD) on stable medication.METHODS: 42 male patients with a history of IHD, aged between 50‐70 yr, on stable medication were randomized into two groups: an experimental group (n = 23) who performed a 2‐year, structured exercise program along with usual treatment; and a control group (n = 19) who were given usual treatment. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a phase III open-label, multicenter, three-arm design, randomized controlled study. This study aims to compare the efficacy, safety, and quality of life of lenalidomide combined with bortezomib or dexamethasone alone as first-line treatment for patients with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM) who have participated in the 3-weekly bortezomib and dexamethasone maintenance therapy for the previous 3-6 cycles after autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT).

Detailed Description
-----------------
The overall survival of patients with multiple myeloma (MM) is around 5 years, and relapse or refractory is the main cause of death after 3-6 3-month cycles of bortezomib and dexamethasone maintenance therapy (MT) after ASCT. In addition to MT after ASCT, there is still no established treatment regimen for patients with relapse or refractory. Lenalidomide is a new drug developed for the treatment of patients with MM who have relapsed or refractory or are refractory to therapy. Lenalidomide plus bortezomib and dexamethasone (LBd) has received orphan designation in the United States and the European Union (EU) for the treatment of MM. The study is a prospective, randomized controlled, multicenter, three-arm design, phase III study, in which patients with refractory and recurrent MM after 3-6 cycles of bortezomib and dexamethasone maintenance therapy after allogeneic stem cell transplantation (ASCT) are recruited and randomized to receive lenalidomide combined with dexamethasone or bortezomib and dexamethasone as first-line treatment for patients with refractory and recurrent multiple myeloma. Key Inclusion Criteria:
1. Diagnosis of cluster of differentiation 20 positive (CD20+) FL grade 1-3a, stage II bulky or stage III/IV.
2. For Part 1A: previously untreated participants who have a Follicular Lymphoma International Prognostic Index (FLIPI)-1 score of 3 to 5 or R/R FL who have not received R-CHOP or R-CVP.
3. For Part 1B: previously untreated participants who have a FLIPI-1 score of 3 to 5.
4. For Part 2: previously untreated participants who have a FLIPI-1 score of 0 to 5.
5. Have measurable disease on cross-sectional imaging documented by diagnostic computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) imaging.
6. Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 0-2.
7. Adequate bone marrow and hepatic function.

Key Exclusion Criteria:
1. Participants with central nervous system lymphoma or leptomeningeal lymphoma.
2. Participants with histological evidence of transformation to a high-grade or diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.
3. Participants with other types of lymphoma (Waldenström macroglobulinemia, grade 3b follicular lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, or small lymphocytic lymphoma).
4. Recent major surgery and history of organ transplantation.
5. A malignancy other than NHL unless adequately treated.
6. Any other significant active disease or medical condition that could interfere with the conduct of the study or put the participant at significant risk.
